N. is joined in her small group by Jane N., Ruth N., Cathy B., and Esther B.. Jane N. is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan of UGX 400,000 to buy more cloth material.

Ruth N. is currently in the business of running a nursery school and is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to construct a new classroom.

Cathy B. is currently in the business of selling hardware and is requesting a loan of UGX 800000 to increase her stock. Esther B. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan of UGX 500 000 to buy a fridge and increase stock.

loans.use: To add medicine to her drug shop

loans.name: Victory Nabingo C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Annet N.. She is currently in the business of operating a market stall and is requesting a loan to add to the business. Annet is 33 years old and is a widow. She has 2 children, aged 10 and 15, both of whom go to school. Each week, Annet makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a modern shade/shed.

Annet is joined in her small group by Teopista N., Annet M., Rosemary N., and Justine M.. Teopista N. has a business in charcoal sales and wants to purchase more sacks of charcoal. Annet M. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to add stock. Rosemary N. operates a business as a herbalist and wants to purchase a fridge. Justine M. is currently in the business of brick laying and is requesting a loan to add capital.

loans.use: To boost business

loans.name: Julia Nelsa

texts.es:
Julia Nelsa R. G. in 46 years old, and completed primary school up to the second grade. She has six children but only two that are dependent on her. She lives in the middle of the small town of Bellavista in the district of Salpo, in the province of Otuzco and the Department of La Libertad, Peru.

In her store that she has set up in a second house that she has just purchased, she sells basic items like candies, sodas, and beer. As well, Julia also earns a living raising cattle, pigs and huachos which she fattens for a time to then sell later at a better price. Her business started with the raising of small animals such as chickens, guinea pigs, and small pigs; later she sold cereals such as wheat, barley and others.

With her first loan of 300.00 PEN that she received from her Communal Bank “Mujeres Trabajadores” (Working Women), she invested in the purchase of two ram sheep.

With this loan of $725.00 (2000.00 PEN) which will be paid in four months, she will buy two large bulls. Her biggest dream is to set up her store to have a larger variety of products.

Translated from Spanish by Diane Lister, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Julia Nelsa R. G. tiene 46 años de edad, estudio hasta el segundo grado de educación primaria. Tiene seis hijos pero solo dos dependen de ella. Vive el centro poblado menor de Bellavista en el distrito de Salpo en la provincia de Otuzco departamento La Libertad – Perú.

En su bodega que ha ambientado en su segunda casa que acaba de comprar, vende productos de primera necesidad, golosinas, gaseosas y cerveza. Así también la señora Julia se dedica a la crianza de ganados, chanchos y huachos el cual engorda por un tiempo para luego venderlo a mayor precio. Su negocio empezó con la crianza de animales menores como gallinas, cuyes y chanchos pequeños, luego vendía cereales de trigo, cebada y otros.

Con su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 que recibió en su Banco Comunal “Mujeres Trabajadoras” lo invirtió en la compra de tres carneros.

Con el préstamo de S/. 2000.00 el cual pagara en cuatro meses comprará dos toros grandes.

Su mayor sueño es implementar su bodega, teniendo mayor variedad de productos.

loans.use: With the loan she will buy two bulls

loans.name: Ermida

texts.en:
Ermida L. S. has a business selling beef in the village of Loma Linda, high in the sierras of the La Libertad Region. She’s run the business for four years and now knows exactly how to make the most of each day. She currently rents a stand in the most popular market.

Ermida is 40 years old and married with two children. Before starting her current business, she knitted. Now she really enjoys interacting with all the different people and helping pay for her children’s education.

A member of the community bank Jesus Nazareno, Ermida is requesting a loan of s/1200 to repay over 6 months. She will use the loan to invest in more beef.

loans.use: She will use the loan to invest in more beef.

loans.name: Bona Theang Group

texts.en: Mrs. Bona T. is the leader of a five-member group in Sala Lek Pram Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She makes yummy Khmer cakes that she sells to the local villagers. Mrs. Bona T. now wants to expand her business.  Unfortunately, she does not have enough money to buy more rice to make more Khmer cakes, thus she is asking for a loan for this goal. She is 44 and the mother of three children:  one is employed in a garment factory while another is attending state school. The remaining child is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Virak P., is unemployed but he always helps his wife to produce Khmer cakes. Previously, Mrs. Bona T. obtained a loan from AMK to start her cake-selling business.

loans.use: Buy rice to make more Khmer cakes.

loans.name: Tarana

texts.en:
Tarana H. was born in 1980. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Zangilan region, settled in the Absheron region. She has run this business for 4 years. 
Tarana is married and has one child. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy  foodstuffs to increase the income form her business.

loans.use: to buy  foodstuffs

loans.name: Thi Thuy Nga's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Thuy Nga, born in 1968 (ID: 03060001) is currently living in Duc Tu, Dong Anh, Hanoi. She would like to borrow a loan of 4.028.000 VND to invest in her small shop, which sells a variety of goods and necessities. Her husband is the head of the hamlet, and they have two sons. Mrs. Nga herself is also an active member of the organization for women in her area, which makes her family very popular and well-liked by everybody. Mrs. Nga purchases goods daily from many sources and sells them to the people in her hamlet. As Mrs. Nga actively participates in many activities in the area, everyone believes in her ability and unanimously votes for her as the head of the group requesting for loans. Her family’s monthly income is about 3.500.000 VND. Other members of her group include:

-Mrs. H. Thi Xuan (born in 1971, ID: 03060007) would like to borrow a loan of 4.028.000 VND to invest in her fruits shop.

-Mrs. T. Thi Thi (born in 1961, ID: 03060002) would like to borrow a loan of 4.028.000 VND to raise poultries.

-Mrs. T. Thi Bich Lan (born in 1977, ID: 03060004) would like to borrow a loan of 4.028.000 VND to raise chickens.

-Mrs. N. Thi Tu (borin in 1968, ID: 03060006) would like to borrow a loan of 4.028.000 VND to invest in her small restaurant.

-Mrs. D. Thi No (born in 1964, ID: 03060003) would like to borrow a loan of 4.028.000 VND to raise chickens.

-Mrs. N. Thi Tinh (born in 1968, ID: 03060005) would like to borrow a loan of 4.028.000 VND to invest in her small café shop.

-Mrs. N. Thi Vong (born in 1963, ID: 03060020) would like to borrow a loan of 4.028.000 VND to raise chickens.

-Mrs. T. Thi Xuan (born in 1964, ID: 03060021) would like to borrow a loan of 1.484.000 VND to invest in her fruits shop.

-Mr. N. Dang Duc (born in 1978, ID: 03060025) would like to borrow a loan of 4.028.000 VND to raise chickens.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa N., Kiva volunteer.

Nguyễn Thị Thúy Nga, sinh năm 1968 (Ms 03060001) hiện đang sống tại Duc Tú, Đông Anh, Hà Nội, chị đăng ký mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hàng tạp hóa. Vợ chồng chị có hai con trai, chồng chị là trưởng thôn, bản thân chị cũng tham gia vào hội phụ nữ, D. đó mọi người trong thôn ai cũng biết và yêu quý vợ chồng chị. Hàng ngày chị thường lấy hàng hóa từ nơi khác về để bán phục vụ những người trong thôn, những lúc rảnh rỗi chị lại tham gia các hoạt động phong trào nên chị rất mạnh dạn và dược mọi người tín nhiệm bầu làm nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn. Đi chợ hàng ngày có thu nhập cộng với lương của chồng đã đem lại cho gia đình chị khoảng 3.500.000 vnđ / tháng. Trong mhóm chị còn có: Hoàng Thị Xuân, sinh năm 1971 (Ms 03060007), mức vay: để đầu tư đi chợ hoa quả. Trần Thị Thị, sinh năm 1961 (Ms 03060002 ), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi. Trần Thị Bích lan, sinh năm 1977(Ms 03060004), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà. Nguyễn Thị Tư, sinh năm 1968 (Ms 03060006 ), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hang ăn uống. Đỗ Thị Sở, sinh năm 1964 (Ms 03060003 ), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà. Nguyễn Thị Tính, sinh năm 1968 (Ms 03060005), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hàng nước giải khát. Nguyễn Thị Vọng, sinh năm 1963 (Ms 03060020), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà. Trần Thị Xuân, sinh năm 1964 (Ms 03060021 ), mức vay: 1.484.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ hoa quả. Nguyễn Đăng Đức, sinh năm 1978 (Ms 03060025), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà.

loans.use: chăn nuôi

loans.name: Sophoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophoeun N., 33, and her husband, Mr. Sophy Kroeun, 29, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1997 and have three children: two daughters and one son. Two of their children are in school.

Mrs. Sophoeun has been a silk weaver for fifteen years, using a skill that she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Mr. Sophy raises cows. Sophoeun is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase silk materials for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving.

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Mr. Van T. is a villager in Tropang Pring Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. He is a palm juice collector who gathers palm juice to process into palm sugar or wine. Aside from from this, he is a cow breeder who raises two cows. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it, so he decided to ask for a loan to buy one more cow for breeding. His wife, Mrs. Sok Ros, is a housewife who cooks very delicious food for her household. Mr. Van T. is 25 years old and the father of a child who is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy one more cow for breeding.

loans.name: Mrs. Kuy Nary's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of twelve members, is located in Prasung Village in Takeo Province. Mrs. Kuy N. is the village bank president, who has been selected by the members. She is 49 years old and a pig breeder. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it, S. she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions after she sells her new pigs. Her husband, Mr. Chab Nan, is a motorbike taxi driver who can generate a small income to support his household. Mrs. Kuy N. has two children, who are attending the local school.

A man who is present in the picture came to accept the loan instead of Mrs. Ngil T., his wife.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Five members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. These allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice A. is married and has four dependents. She has received no formal education. Beatrice sells fried fish to food sellers at a popular place called Air Force near Shama, which she has done since 1994. She has started selling clothing and footwear in addition to the fish she processes for sale. Her husband is a military officer. Beatrice uses her income to assist her husband in providing the basic needs of the family. Beatrice will use the loan to purchase more fresh fish to be fried and smoked. She wants to also invest in her now growing clothing business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Beatrice plans to reinvest into the business.

loans.use: Beatrice will use the loan to purchase more fresh fish to be fried.

loans.name: Abdullah

texts.en:
Abdullah D. is a trader. He sells goods like footwear, fabric and so on at Abrobemu; he has been doing this since 1995. He is married and has five dependents, and his wife is also a trader. He has received education through senior high school.

Abdullah intends to use the loan to buy fabric and more sandals for resale at the market. The profit he makes will be used to pay the school fees of his children and also to expand his business.

On the table are some fabrics - samples of what he sells

loans.use: To buy fabric and more sandals for resale at the market.

loans.name: Mrs. Phan But Village Bank Group

texts.en:
EleV. people in Trapang Krapue village in Kampong Chhnang province have formed a village bank loan group and Mrs. Phan B. is the village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice, B. her field is infertile and she does not have enough money to repair an irrigation pump. Thus, she decided to request for a loan to purchase fertilizer and fix the pump in order to water her field. Mrs. Phan B. is a 66-year-old widow with three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the third is a construction worker.

All the members in this group loan are committed to end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal until the very end of the loan's term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and repair an irrigation pump.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce A. is 35 year old, married and has four children. All her children are in school. She lives with her husband in the house they were married in, at Koforidua, a suburb of Offinso, in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She is an achiever and a resourceful young woman. She loves selling goods, the business through which she makes her living. 

Joyce has been trading in oranges, bananas, and food stuffs like plantain at the road side of Koforidua for eight years now. She treks to surrounding villages in the Central part of Ghana to purchase bulk supplies of oranges, bananas and plantains from the farmers and retails them to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to purchase enough supplies to make sufficient profit to support her family. She wants to use part of the profit to support her kid’s education.
  
With the loan, she would like to purchase bulk supplies of oranges, bananas and plantain to scale up her sales. She believes the loan would enable her to produce more income to support her business growth. Joyce belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame Nti’ which means for Christ Sake. She hopes that a loan of GH¢1000 would make her business grow by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more and support her husband in taking care of the home.

loans.use: To buy fruits like oranges, bananas and plantain.

loans.name: Terencio

texts.es:
En el municipio de Somotillo de la ciudad de Chinandega el señor Terencio V. se dedica a su actividad agrícola de siembra de maíz el cual al momento que se da la cosecha él lo extrae en grandes sacos los cuales después son vendidos. La situación que por mucho tiempo ha atravesado el señor Terencio es que en su comunidad no poseen energía eléctrica por ser una zona muy alejada y es por este motivo que decidió solicitar un crédito a Ceprodel para la compra de un panel solar para su casa el cual tenga acceso por lo menos a dos lámparas para alumbrarse por la noche y llevar a cabo su actividad agrícola.

Al haber adquirido el panel requiere cancelar dicha deuda y por esto espera en que Ceprodel le beneficie con un crédito para la compra del panel y de esta forma continuar con el mantenimiento de su familia compuesta por su cónyuge y sus dos pequeños hijos a los que tiene que proporcionarles la educación escolar que ellos requieren.
texts.en:
In the municipality of Chinandega city Mr. Terencio V. farms corn. Currently it is the harvest and he harvests the corn in large sacks that will later be sold. The situation that Terencio has faced for a long time is that in his community they don’t have electrical power because they are in a distant zone, and because of this he decided to solicit Ceprodel for a loan in order to buy a solar panel for his home so he may have the use of at least two lamps to provide light at night and enable him to finish his farming. Upon acquiring the panel he will need to pay the bill so he hopes that Ceprodel will provide him a loan to help purchase the panel and in this way continue to support his family which consists of his wife and two small children for whom he has to provide the education that they need.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for a solar panel for his home

loans.name: Gulmira

texts.en:
Gulmira T. is twenty-four years old. She and her husband have a two-year-old son and a tremendous desire to build a solid home and fill it with harmony. They also show a great deal of optimism and confidence in their agricultural endeavors, putting all their effort in the farming of vegetables, which they later offer to wholesalers. All this effort is paying off because they have recently started the construction of their own house. This has been a great source of motivation for them and so they want to improve the quality of their products through better use of fertilizers and seeds. They are requesting a loan of $800 which will help them finish the construction of their dream house.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History:
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora J. is currently in the business of selling beans and mangoes and is requesting a loan to buy beans, dale, rice, and other food to sell.  Flora is 45 years old and is married to a policeman. She has 5 children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy produce and grains to sell

loans.name: Faaiuga

texts.en: Faaiuga S., 44, is married with three children.  She has six years of experience in the vegetable garden business. She sells to the villagers and public, three days per week. She has not had any previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 tala (~$125 US).  SPBD loans are Faaiuga’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, spade, wheelbarrow, rake, water hose and vegetable seeds for tomatoes, cucumbers, cabbages, etc.

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en: Taiwo A. is 32 years old and married without a child. She sells medicines and provisions. She is requesting for the loan amount of N40, 000 to purchase more medicines and provisions to sell. She says thanks to kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and medicines to sell

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana P. is from the city of San Vicente Alto, Oroquieta City. She is 65 years old. Juana is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Juana owns & operates a rug making & potholder business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling general hand-woven products to tourists and local community members. Juana has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2001, Juana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juana is requesting a new loan of 2500 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to make rugs & potholders. This loan will be the 13th loan taken out by Juana from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

loans.name: Sobirchon

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 


Собирчон -мужчина в возрасте 37 лет, женат имеет троих детей .Работает убойщик скота.Он занимается откормом и продажей говяжьего мяса на рынке города Худжанда.У него очень много постоянных клиентов которые у него покупают.Он хочет получить кредит для закупа молодого скота, который откормив хочет зарезать и продать мясо в розницу.Он благодарен KIVA за сотрудничество и финансирование.
texts.en:
Sobirchon is a 37-year-old man who is married and has three children. He works as a beef butcher. He is involved with the care and sale of beef at the market in the city of Khujand. He has very many repeat clients who buy from him. He wants to receive a loan in order to buy young cattle, which when raised he wants to slaughter and to sell the meat at retail. He is thankful to Kiva for the collaboration and financing. --- MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: care and sale of cattle

loans.name: Shurentsetseg

texts.en: Shurentsetseg Y. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and two teenage children in Arhangai Province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her two sons are both high school students. Shurentsetseg sells meat in small pieces at the local food market. She has been renting a small stall at the local market and selling mostly mutton and beef to locals for the past ten years. She started the meat business in early 1999 with small capital of 300,000 MNT. Since then, she has gained significant experience and has regularly visiting local customers. Her business capital is currently exceeding 2,500,000 MNT (8 times more than the starting capital). Her husband always helps in her business. He drives his small truck to nearby herder families and purchases cattle and sheep for the business. She requests a loan to purchase more meat for her business and plans to use the profit to get a full repair for her husband's truck.

loans.use: To purchase meat for her business.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa R. is from the village of Panalsalan. She is 42 years old. Elsa is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Elsa owns and operates a furniture-making business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Elsa has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elsa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa is requesting a loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Elsa from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria D. R. is from the village of Bacolod, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old. Gloria is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Gloria owns and operates a tailoring business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing tailoring services to local community members. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gloria joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and thread. This will be the first loan taken out by Gloria from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and thread

loans.name: Blanca Marina

texts.es: Blanca Marina L. G. vive en el municipio de Tonacatepeque en el departamento de San Salvador. Blanca Vive con su esposo y sus tres hijos todos menores de edad de 16,14 y 13 años respectivamente. Todos estudian en la escuela, y se ayudan mutuamente con los deberes y tareas. Blanca trabaja en su propio negocio de corte y confección, donde ha aprendido a tejer y coser. Actualmente solicita un préstamo para reinvertir en su negocio, ya que necesita vender más, para tratar de brindar a sus hijos la educación formal que ella y su esposo nunca tuvieron.
texts.en:
Blanca Marina L. G. lives in the town of Tonacatepeque in the district of San Salvador. She lives with her husband and three dependent children (ages 16, 14, and 13). They all attend school and help one another with their homework and assignments. Blanca works at her own dressmaking business, where she learned how to knit and sew.

At the moment, she is requesting a loan to reinvest into her business. She needs to sell more of her merchandise so that she can provide the formal education to her children that she and her husband never had.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials to increase production

loans.name: Charles' Group

texts.en:
Charles N. is the leader of his lending group in Mukono. A friendly and hard-working man, he has operated a fish-selling business from Mukono for four years now. He gets his fish from many sites in and around Mukono, based on where the prices are most favorable, thus enabling him to make some profits out of his transactions. He is requesting a loan to buy more fish for resale. His goal is to open an additional stall to sell from so he earn more in order to pay for his children’s school fees with ease.

Charles is married with five children, the eldest six years old and in primary one; he also takes care of three grandparents.

loans.use: Buying more fish for resale.

loans.name: Enhtuvshin

texts.en: Enkhtuvshin is 26 years old and lives with his wife and four-year-old son in Arkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent home. Enkhtuvshin owns a woodworking business in town and his wife helps him run the business. He usually makes wooden furniture for gers. He began his business in 2006 with working capital of 200,000 tugrug (~140 USD) and has since grown the working capital to 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD). Enkhtuvshin’s products are known through town for their high quality and durability. He is requesting a 900,000 tugrug (~630 USD) loan to purchase more wood in order to make more products and increase his sales.

loans.use: To purchase more wood.

loans.name: Juan Alberto

texts.en: For years, Juan Alberto T. has dedicated himself to the sale of natural medicines. He purchases his products, including teas, salves, and herbs, from the market in Managua. He has clients in the nearby cities of Leon and Chinandega. Juan Alberto also sells his medicines to pharmacies. He has a motorbike to ensure his transportation from place to place. It is also more economical than using a car. Juan has three children ages 13, 16, and 19. All of them are currently in school. The oldest child attends the university. Juan Alberto’s partner is a housewife. He dreams of having a great pharmacy filled with many medicinal products.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Helida Atieno

texts.en:
Helida is 57 years old, married and is blessed with five children. Her business is located at Kona in Eldoret.

She was introduced to KADET by Patrick Mwangi. With the loan she is taking from KADET, Helida plans to purchase more maize stock to sell to customers. Her dream is to improve her business and to be able to afford a permanent home one day for her family. 


About KADET:  The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: http://www.kadet.co.ke/

loans.use: to purchase more maize stock to sell to customers

loans.name: Edy Orlando

texts.en:
Edy is 34 years old and lives with his common-law wife and their four-year-old daughter.  Edy and his wife are dairy cow farmers and currently have four dairy cows for milk production.  Edy sells the milk to Pil, a large local dairy company in Cochabamba.  Pil then uses the raw milk to produce all sorts of milk products, including yogurt and cheese.  Edy has been farming since he was a little boy, helping his mother on the family farm.  His family currently lives in Edy's childhood home.

Edy's mother recently got sick and because she had to continue working, she strained her body more and more. Sadly, about a year ago Edy's mother passed away, which has left him to care for his 17-year-old brother.  Edy also works as a taxi driver, but now that he needs to take care of his brother, the earnings from that job haven't been sufficient for his family's needs.  

Edy will use this loan from CIDRE to purchase another dairy cow.  This will increase his milk production, which he hopes will grow his earnings so that he can improve his family's quality of life.  Edy has many dreams, including owning his own taxi, paying his brother's school fees, and remodeling their family home.  Also, Edy and his wife are proudly expecting another little one on the way, and they are very happy they have this loan to help grow their income for their new baby.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Mey

texts.en:
Mey L. was born in 1959 and is the good mother of three children. All three of them are out of school and currently work in the garment factory.

Mey is an animal raiser who has four years' experience in this business. She also distills wine, and she feeds the leftovers from the process to her animals. Her husband assists her with the business activities (he appears in the picture).

Because raising animals is the primary method for Mey to raise income, she is asking for capital to help her business be more efficient and successful.

loans.use: Capital to help her business be more efficient and successful

loans.name: Andrea Maximina

texts.es:
La señora  ANDREA MAXIMINA R. D. R. tiene 53 años, vive en el distrito deL PORVENIR, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. Pertenece al Banco Comunal CARIDAD II. La socia presenta estudios  hasta 6to D. primaria, refiere que es D. la sierra y que desD. niña se dedicó a trabajar en el campo, está casada y tiene 6 hijos D. los cuales 2 dependen económicamente D. ella. La socia se dedica a realizar manualidades como tejidos y bordados que los importa al interior del país.
Con su primer crédito D. 300.00 nuevos soles, comprará cosméticos como: colonias, perfumes , cremas, talcos, etc.
Con este crédito D. 300.00 nuevos soles, piensa comprar lana al por mayor para atender los pedidos D. chompas, bufandas, guantes, chales, etc que tiene pendientes por enviar. Ella sueña con exportar sus manualidades al extranjero.
texts.en:
Miss ANDREA MAXIMINA R. D. R. is 53 years old, she lives in the EL PORVENIR district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department in Peru. She is a member of the Communal Bank CARIDAD II. This member has a 6th graD. primary school education, she is from the mountain and since she was little she worked on the field. She is married and has 6 children, 2 of whom are still economically dependent. The member is now dedicated to artcrafts like embroidery and knitting. She imports these to the interior of the country. With her first credit of 300.00 new soles, she will purchase cosmetics such as:colognes, perfumes, creams, powders, etc. With this credit of 300.00 new soles, she will also purchase wholesale wool to meet the requests for pending scarfs, mittens, shawls, sweaters, etc. She dreams of exporting her crafts outsiD. of Peru.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: PURCHASE WHOLESALE WOOL

loans.name: Natalia

texts.es: La Sra. Natalia vive en  la zona de coqueni en casa alquilada y cuenta con una tienda de barrio que tambien es alquilada ubicada en la laguna de cota cota actividad con la que mantiene a su hogar y a sus 2 hijas quienes la ayudan en la tienda en su tiempo libre ya que las dos tambien estudian,y el esposo es transportista y la ayuda con los gastos del hogar, ella es muy responsable en el pago de sus cuotas, se pudo notar que el negocio de la clente esta en constante crecimiento la Sra. Natalia esta muy agradecida con la institucion por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Natalia lives in the Coqueni area in a rented house. She has a neighborhood store, which is also rented. It is located in Laguna de Cota Cota. The store supports her household and her two daughters. Her daughters help her in the store during their free time. Both of her daughters also go to school. Her husband is a driver, and he helps her with the household expenses. She is very responsible about making her payments. It can be noted that the client’s business is constantly growing. Natalia is very grateful to the institution for the help.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Tufanye Asaba Rosemary Group

texts.en: A. Rosemary, 21, is a hardworking business lady who is married and has three children, two of whom are going to school. She has been farming for three years. She is using the loan to get a tractor to plow her field, and to buy fertilizer, seeds, and so on to help her grow a better crop. She is a hardworking business lady who hopes to build a house in the future.

loans.use: To use a tractor to plow her field, to buy fertilizer, seeds, and so on for her farm.

loans.name: Bosede

texts.en: Bosede  is married to a land surveyor and they have four children. She has a shop where she sells drinks to make a living. She loves her business because of the one-to-one interaction that she has with her customers. Bosede is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more drinks to sell. In the future, she hopes to own a world-class drinks shop and be able to give her children a good quality education. She says thank you and promises to repay her Kiva loan promptly.

loans.use: To purchase drinks to sell

loans.name: Bogdan

texts.en:
Bogdan is married and has two daughters. He is an entrepreneur from Ivano-Frankivsk. He owns a transportation business and offers taxi services in the territory of Ukraine. Bogdan launched this business about nine years ago. Currently, he gets 7,000 Grivnyas of income each month.  

Bogdan is seeking a loan of 7,000 Grivnyas to repair the running gear of his car. He has much experience working in the field of transportation. He used to be a public van driver, but then he decided to quit and start his own venture. Bogdan’s transportation business is the only source of income for his family of four. He is hoping to continue with this business and make some savings for his children’s college.

loans.use: To repair the car used in his business

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is 42 years old and married with six children. They range in age from 5 to 22 years old, with the youngest five all attending school.

Richard runs a mixed farm in western Kenya, near the town of Kitale, where he has been farming for over five years. His main business is milk production, which he sells in the local market, while he also earns income as a casual day laborer working at the local college.

Richard is taking out his first loan with Juhudi Kilimo for Kes 30,000 to improve his poultry farming operations. He will be increasing his stock as well as purchasing additional farm inputs to improve productivity. The extra income from this loan will help provide for his family's needs, now and in the future.

Richard would also like to expand his farm over time, purchasing more land and eventually owning at least five high yield dairy cows.

loans.use: To expand his poultry farm

loans.name: Serious Women Group

texts.en:
Gorbu V. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Serious Women. She is 39 years old, married, and has four children who range from 7 to 20 years old. She did not have the opportunity to go school.

For 5 years, Gorbu has been selling palm oil at the Kingsville #7 community Market in Margibi County, Liberia. She sells good quality palm oil, which keeps customers returning. Gorbu plans to use her 10,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 50,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy additional palm oil. Her goal is to send her children to school, build a house for her family and give them medical attention when needed.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Gorbu is the one holding the sign. Korpo W. is inset at lower right.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy additional palm oil.

loans.name: Belia Cecilia

texts.es:
Belia G. vive con sus padres y una hermana en San Juan Nepomuceno, municipio de Bolívar, en un barrio donde muchos de sus habitantes pertenecen al sector educativo y  la comunidad en general se caracteriza por ser vecinos solidarios.
Ella estudió Administración Hotelera y vivió 20 años en Cartagena, donde conoció a mucha gente y le surgió la idea de vender ropa o prendas de vestir, realizando su mercadeo inicial mediante catálogos. Belia hace un poco mas de 2 años, trabajó en una empresa que cerraron, y con sus ahorros construyó un local y creo su negocio “Belia Boutique” cuando se fue a vivir nuevamente a San Juan Nepomuceno, lugar donde nació y sigue atendiendo a su clientela de Cartagena y agregando a su negocio nuevos clientes de San Juan Nepomuceno. Para ella su negocio ha sido muy importante, porque depende económicamente de él, aunque también recibe sus ingresos de su apartamento, arrendado porque vive en casa de sus padres. En la actualidad aplica a primer crédito con la Fundación  Mario Santo Domingo por valor de $ 2.300.000 para comprar prendas de vestir para damas caballeros y niños, y calzado elegante ya solicitado por sus clientes.

Su sueño es ampliar su local y más adelante  tener un carro para viajar a traer mercancías desde Bogotá y Medellín. Su gran desafío fue quedar desempleada y sostenerse mediante su negocio y otro de sus grandes desafíos y aprendizaje, fue la cuando hizo una oferta inicial de créditos a pesonas que no conocía y perdió parte de su dinero ahorrado, porque las cuentas por cobrar crecieron, pero quedaron dineros incobrables, con los que ya no cuenta;  finalmente  con esta experiencia negativa aprendió a ser muy cuidadosa en la selección de sus clientes  y en la actualidad  eso es precisamente lo que hace elegirlos bien.
texts.en:
Belia G. lives with her parents and a sister in San Juan Nepomuceno in the Bolívar municipality. She lives in a neighborhood where many of the inhabitants belong to the educational sector. In general, the people in the community are characterized as being supportive neighbors. She studied Hotel Administration, and she lived in Cartagena for 20 years. She knew a lot of people there, and she got the idea to sell clothes. She got her initial merchandise through catalogs. A little over two years ago Belia worked for a company that closed. She used her savings to build her place and created her business, Belia Boutique. Once again she went to live in San Juan Nepomuceno, the place where she was born. She continues to take care of her customers from Cartagena, and she is adding to her business with new customers from Juan Nepomuceno. The business has been very important to her because she is economically dependent upon it. This is true even though she receives income from her apartment, which is rented because she lives in her parents’ house. She is currently asking for her first loan with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo for 2,300,000 COP. She will buy clothing and elegant footwear for women, men, and children, which has been requested by her customers. Her dream is to expand her place and to later on have a car. She would use the car to travel and bring merchandise from Bogotá and Medellín. Her big challenge is continuing to be unemployed and supporting herself with her business. Another big challenge and lesson was when she gave credit to people she did not know, and she lost part of the money she had saved. The bills she had to pay grew, and there was money she could not collect. She does not have that now. Finally, with this negative experience she learned to be very careful choosing her customers. That is precisely what she now does, and it makes her choose them well.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing and elegant footwear for women, men, and children; which has been requested by her customers.

loans.name: God's Blessing Group

texts.en:
Marthaline S. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called God’s Blessing. She is 39 years old, married, and has three children who range from 8 to 22 years old. Marthaline was only able to attend school through 5th grade.

For 8 years, Marthaline has been selling fish at the Red Light Market, which is the largest market in Liberia. She says that she provides her customers with good quality fish, which keeps them coming to her for business.

Marthaline plans to use her 5,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 25,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more fish.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Marthaline is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish.

loans.name: Norlan Antonio

texts.es:
El joven Norlan es activo y trabajador, tiene 23 años de edad, se dedica ala  venta de productos lácteos y venta de leña, lleva dos años en las ventas en donde ha captado su clientela, su esposa renuncio a su trabajo para poder invertir en la venta de tortilla y así poder cuidar de su niño que aun esta pequeño. 
El joven Norlan desde horas temprana sale a vender su leche agria, crema, queso y leña, pero hay días que sus ventas no superan ni para la alimentación lo que le preocupa. Como otros días bueno que termina la venta temprano, con este financiamiento invertirá en  más cantidad de leche para producir más los productos de leche agria, crema, cuajada y extender sus ventas a muchos mas bario de la capital con el fin de obtener mejores ganancias como hacer crecer su clientela.
texts.en:
Norlan is an active young man and a hard worker. He is 23 years old and he sells dairy products and firewood. He has been selling for two years and he has an established clientele. His wife quit her job to make tortillas full time and so that she would have more time to take care of their very young son. Norlan sets out in the very early hours of the day to sell his complement of milk, cream, cheese and firewood. But there are some days that he doesn't sell enough even to buy food for his family and he worries. There are good days when he can even wrap things up early. He plans to invest this loan in the purchase of more milk to make greater quantities of dairy products such as yogurt, cream, and cheese curds. He will then be in a position to extend his sales to many others in the district, with the goal of improving his earnings and expanding his client base.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase milk to produce yogurt, cream, and cheese curds.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
La Socia pertenece al banco comunal “COLQUECANCHA”; Nuestra Socia vive en la comunidad de Raqchi perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba del departamento de Cusco.

Nuestra socia es la Sra. Virginia, Nuestra socia tiene 18 años de edad, la socia es conviviente y vive con su pareja desde hace  1 año; Nuestra socia se dedica a la agricultura como actividad principal y su pareja se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería, Nuestra socia está aprendiendo en sus ratos libres hacer pulseras con lanas de diversas texturas y colores y los diferentes motivos; Nuestra socia también cría gallinas y pollitos. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar junto con su conyugue una vaquita tierna.

Nuestra socia agradece a todos los inversionistas que hacen  posible la realización de este sueño y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Virginia belongs to the Colquecancha community bank; she lives in the Raqchi community, Urubamba, Cusco. She is 18 and has lived with her partner for 1 year. Her primary activity is agriculture, and her partner is a farmer and rancher. In her free time, she is learning to make bracelets in different motifs with wool of various textures and colours. She also raises little hens and chickens. She is requesting this loan to buy a young cow with her partner. She is grateful to all the investors who are making this dream possible, and promises to repay the loan on time.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a young cow

loans.name: Seang Ey's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Seang Ey S. is 49 years old and was chosen to serve as village bank president by the other fourteen members, who all live in Peam Reang Leu village in Kandal province and have different businesses for which they will use their portion of this group loan.  Mrs. Seang Ey S. herself is duck seller in the local market while her husband, Mr. Hoeun Tun, is a teacher in the local school, and they are able to earn a small income to support their family. Mrs. Seang Ey S. will use her loan to buy more ducks to sell, and hopefully earn more profits to improve the life of her family. The couple has four children who all are students and also support their mother with the business.

loans.use: To buy more ducks for selling.

loans.name: Adjowavi Josephine

texts.fr:
A 43 ans, adjossey adjowavi reste encore très dynamique. Elle achète et revend des chaussures.
Elle vend une gamme variée de chaussures pour femmes, hommes et enfants qu’elle expose sur un étalage à son domicile. Elle exerce cette  activité depuis 3 ans et maitrise assez bien le secteur.
Le crédit sollicité est destiné à l’achat de nouveaux stocks de chaussures pour satisfaire la demande de la clientèle.
Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant.
texts.en:
At 43 years, Adjowavi A. remains very dynamic. She is married and mother of a child. She buys and resells shoes. She sells a varied range of shoes for women, men and children which she displays at her residence. She has carried on this activity for 3 years and controls rather well this sector of the market. The requested credit is intended for the purchase of new stocks of shoes to satisfy the request of customers.

Translated from French by Mark Latour, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of shoes

loans.name: Poderosas 23 De Marzo Group

texts.es:
La asociación comunal “Poderosas 23 D. Marzo” pertenece al Centro Focal D. Panamericana.  Esta asociación se ha reagrupado para solicitar un crédito D. forma conjunta, este es su primer ciclo, tienen como presidenta a la señorita Milenka Araceli C. M., la mencionada asociación comunal pertenece al Centro Focal D. Panamericana.  La señorita Milenka tiene como negocio la venta D. carne D. res, con el apoyo D. sus padres, quienes le enseñaron el oficio desD. la práctica en cortes como la administración.
Es poco frecuente encontrar a una Presidenta tan joven, pues Milenka cuenta con 21 años D. edad, indudablemente el que esté a punto D. graduarse como Profesora D. fisica-quimica, le ha dado la seguridad a la asociación para darle este cargo.

Las integrantes D. la asociación comunal tienen diversos negocios:  venta D. fruta, venta D. joyas, tienda D. barrio, venta D. productos D. belleza, venta D. carne y conductor D. taxi
texts.en:
The “Poderosas 23 D. Marzo" (Powerful Women of March 23rd) Communal Association is affiliated with a Panamericana Regional Center. The association has reorganized in order to solicit loans in a collective form. This is its 1st loan cycle. The current president is Miss Milenka Araceli, whose business is selling beef. She is assisted in the business by her parents who taught her the skills, from making cuts to administration. It is rare to encounter a president so young. Milenka is 21 years old and is at the point of graduation as a teacher of physics-chemistry. She has given the association good reason to offer her the responsibility. The members of the communal association have diverse businesses: selling fruit, selling jewelry, operating a neighborhood store, selling beauty products, selling meat, and driving a taxi.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING MEAT FOR HER BUTCHER SHOP

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene P. is from the village of Pedlagahan, Gingoog City. She is 37 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Arlene owns a sari-sari (variety) shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Arlene has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Arlene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Arlene from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rejane

texts.en:
Rejane M. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Buena Suerte, El Nido, Palawan. She earns her living by operating one business venture: a bar and restaurant located on the main street of El Nido surrounded by hotel and pension houses of the area and a very affordable restaurant in front of the El Nido Terminal.

Rejane joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past two loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rejane has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 3rd loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000 which she intends to use to purchase more raw materials so that she can continue to save up for the future of her family and business. Rejane M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials for the businesses

loans.name: Aitilla's Group

texts.en:
Aitilla I. is thirty-nine and married. She has two daughters who are four and eight. Her elder daughter goes to school and her younger daughter stays at home. Her husband is a guard at local school. Aitilla works at the local school also as a cleaner. 

She and her husband also breed cattle. She started seven years ago upon the suggestion of her friend. Now, she gets 4,000 soms from cattle breeding. She applied for a loan and successfully repaid it. She could increase quantity of cattle to seven.  She wants to purchase additional cattle for breeding, therefore she has applied for another loan. In the near future, with the profits from cattle breeding, she is planning to buy furniture and household appliances for the house and a bicycle for her little daughter. 

Group members:

- Kuluipa A. is the treasurer of the group. She is thirty-eight and divorced. She has two sons. They are thirteen and nine years old. She earns money by providing services of making capital repairs at the school. Four years ago, she decided to start cattle breeding due to the absence of employment opportunities. Right now, her profits from cattle breeding are 2,000 soms monthly. She wants to increase the quantity of cattle she owns because it would allow her to increase her profits. Unfortunately, she is not able to purchase additional cattle, therefore she has applied for a loan in order to have an access to additional funds. With the profits from cattle breeding, Kuluipa is planning to buy household appliances for her house. With future profits, she is planning to buy a one-room flat, a computer for her children, and a bicycle. 

- Asanbai M. is fifty and divorced. He lives alone. Right now, he is a guard for the local administration. At the same time, he earns additional money by making capital repairs. He started providing capital repairs to peple in 2008 and he receives 2000 soms monthly additional from it.  Asanbai is planning to buy construction materials and make capital repairs at his own house in order to make it more comfortable. Still, he needs money for purchases. Therefore he has applied for a loan. In the near future, he plans to start construction of new house on the area that he already bought. 

- Elmira K. is forty-two and married. She has three children: her sons are twenty and twelve and her daughter is seventeen. Her elder son is a student at the Academy of the Ministry of Internal Affairs, her daughter and youngest son go to school. For the past three years she has been a farmer and cattle-breeder. She applied for a loan for 25,000 soms previously and bought cattle. She fattened and resold the cattle and made good money on it. Therefore, she decided t continue. Now, she makes 10,000 soms monthly from it. She is applying for a loan to have funds for purchasing additional cattle for breeding. With the help of the profits from cattle breeding, she will be able to pay the tuition fee for he son at the Academy of Internal Affairs. She is planning that by enlarging her cattle herd she will be able to increase her profits, and therefore pay the tuition fees of her daughter when she enters an institution of higher education. For now, her plan is to save money for her daughter's education. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (staying environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: purchasing cattle

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean D. is from the town of Banga. She is 55 years old. Jean is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Jean raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Jean has been engaged in farming since she was in her 20s.

Jean joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jean has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jean is requesting a new loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Ulugbek

texts.en:
Ulugbek E. is an optimistic and positive person who works to build a prosperous future for his children and maintain their lifestyle. Ulugbek is 44 years-old and a citizen of Kyrgyz's southern city, Osh. He graduated from industrial college and worked as a mechanical engineer at a brick factory. But the money which Ulugbek earned working  around the clock, didn’t cover the needs of his family of three children. In 1994, with the wholehearted support of his wife, who worked as a teacher at the local school, Ulugbek decided to start his business selling office supplies. Using their money, which they put away for a rainy day, this couple began to sell office suppliers and bags at the local market. Due to strong efforts and hard work, Ulugbek managed to buy a house and a used car for his family. His conscientious attitude to work allowed him to gain a reputation of being a responsible businessman. 

But in June 2010, when violent clashes caused by the deposed political regime broke out in the city of Osh, Ulugbek lost his business. His sales shop at the market was robbed and looted. But Ulugbek didn’t give up and decided to resume his lost business and continue his activities. For this very reason, Ulugbek is applying for a loan of 100,000 KGS, which he needs to restart his business. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase office supply goods for retail sales

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan K. lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. 

Susan has a beauty-salon business. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works seven days out of every week. Susan sells her products in a shop on a retail basis.    

Susan has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy boxes of cream, braids and weaves. She also generates additional income through hiring out her motorcycle.

The main business challenges for Susan include seasonality and transportation. Her goal and aspiration for her business is to own a bridal salon. She also would like to build her own house.  

Susan lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, feeding the family and rent.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of cream relaxers, braids and weaves

loans.name: Enhtur

texts.en: Enhtur B. is 27 years old, married, and has one child. The family lives in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife works as a cashier in the library. Enhtur operates and manages a traditional shoe-making business. He has been making traditional boots called Buriad and sells them to the wholesale buyers at the Narantuul, the largest market in the city. He started his business in 2002 and has gained significant experience over the years.  One day, he would like to own her own workplace. Enhtur is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more supplies and materials for his shoe-making business.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies and materials for his shoe-making business

loans.name: Francisco I Madero Group

texts.es: Este grupo se llama Francisco I Madero porque así se llama la calle donde se reúne el grupo, está ubicado en el estado de Morelos en México, el grupo está conformado por 9 integrantes.Cristina E. R. es la tesorera del grupo, tiene 37 años, estudio hasta el 3er año de secundaria, es serigrafista, tiene en total 3 hijos: una mujer y 2 varones.  Ella se dedica a la serigrafía negocio que inicio hace 4 años, solicita el préstamo para comprar  plástico para hacer bolsas, ya que se acerca la temporada navideña y es cuando más trabajo tiene, al momento de solicitar el crédito se siente contenta porque tendrá material para cumplir con los pedidos de sus clientes. Quiere este préstamo para surtir de mercancía su negocio, uno de sus proyectos para el siguiente año es comprarse una camioneta para distribuir su mercancía ya que por el momento pide prestado un vehículo para trasportar sus artículos
texts.en: This group is called Francisco I Madero as this is the name of the street where the group meets, it is located in the state of Morelos in Mexico, the group is made up of 9 members.Cristina E. R. is the treasurer of the group, she is 37 years old, she studied up to the 3rd year of middle school, she is a screenprinter, she has 3 children: one girl and 2 boys.  She has a screenprinting business which she began 4 years ago, she is requesting the loan to buy plastic to make bags, as it is nearing the Christmas season and this is when she has the most work, at this time of requesting the loan she is feeling happy because she will have material to complete the orders of her customers. She wants this loan to supply her business with stock, one of her projects for next year is to buy a van to distribute her stock as at the moment she has to borrow a vehicle to transport her goods.

loans.use: To buy material to make screenprinted bags.

loans.name: Nilda Alberta

texts.es:
En el cantón Rocafuerte se  reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal Mujeres Trabajadoras. Este lugar se lo conoce por sus deliciosos dulces que preparan los lugareños y que son reconocidos en todo el país.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Nilda,  ella tiene 44 años de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual ha procreado 5 hijos, cuatro son mayores de edad y el menor estudia en colegio y es el que vive con ella. El marido se dedica a la agricultura. Hace muchos años ella estudió belleza y es a eso lo que ella se dedica.
 
Tiene un salón de belleza, donde sus clientes llegan a realizarse muchos trabajos de belleza personal, realiza cortes de cabello, tinturados peinados y maquillajes, trabaja todos los días desde las 8am hasta las 18h00, hay días que tiene mucho trabajo y su hija es quien le ayuda.  También vende productos y tratamientos de belleza.

Este crédito es para comprar shampoo, tintes, cremas  y otros productos de belleza. Es socia del Banco Comunal hace dos ciclos y le gusta por la facilidad para realizar los pagos. Su sueño es tener un gran spa.
texts.en:
Every fortnight the members of the “Mujeres Trabajadoras” (Hard-Working Women) community bank meet in Rocafuerte canton.  This place is known for the delicious desserts and sweets which its residents make and which are are known throughout the country.

Here we meet Nilda.  She is 44 years old and lives with her common-law husband.  They have 5 children; four are grown up and the youngest is in school and still lives at home.  Nilda's husband is a farmer.  She studied to be a beautician and this is her business activity.

Nilda has a beauty salon where her customers come to receive a number of different personal beauty treatments.  She cuts hair, colors hair and does make up.  She works every day from 8.00am to 6.00pm.  There are days when she has a lot of work and her daughter helps her out.  She also sells beauty products and treatments.

This loan will be used to buy shampoo, dyes, creams and other beauty products.  Nilda has been a member of her community bank for two loan cycles.  She likes the ease with which she can make her payments.  Her dream is to own a big spa.

loans.use: To buy shampoo, dyes, creams and beauty products

loans.name: Socorro

texts.es: Socorro tiene 36 años de edad y es viuda hace 10 años, tiene 2 hijos Joseph de 19 y Nelly de 14 años, viven en su casa propia. La actividad principal de Socorro es dedicarse a la agricultura, en su parcela  tiene cacao, hojas de coca y café. Viene labrando la tierra hace 18 años, desde que falleció su amado esposo, ella trabaja con ayuda de los jornaleros, siendo su producto más rentable el cacao, ya que sus granos son de primera calidad y los vende a la Cooperativa Agraria, en donde es socia y percibe  al culimar el año los incentivos por entregar sus mejores granos. Con el tiempo aspira a comprar más terrenos y sembrar  cacao, para así poder sacar adelante a sus  queridos hijos. Este es su tercer crédito con MFP, por lo cual ella se siente comprometida de seguir apostando por este medio, ya que le permite mejorar su calidad de vida. En su banco comunal es una socia muy respetada  por ser muy puntual en sus pagos. Con el crédito que solicita, adquirirá abono y  herramientas; para así poder cumplir con sus responsabilidades y mejorar la producción de sus cultivos.
texts.en: Socorro is 36 years and she has been a widow for 10 years. She has 2 children, Joseph who is 19 years old and Nelly who is 14 years old. They live in their own home. Socorro's primary business is agriculture and on her land she has cocoa, coca leaves, and coffee. She has been working the land for the last 18 years, since her beloved husband passed away. She has been getting help from migrant workers. Her most profitable product is cocoa, given that the grains are of premium quality. She sells them to an agrarian cooperative where she is a member. At the year's end she is able to collect incentives from them for having given them her best products. In time she aspires to purchase more land to sell cocoa and to be able to provide for her children. This is her third loan from MFP (Kiva Field Partner). She feels committed to keep up with these loans because they permit her to improve their quality of life. She is a much respected member of her community bank, for being always on time with her payments. The loan she requests will be used to purchase fertilizers and tools, in order to keep up with responsibilities and to improve the production of her plantations.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and tools.

loans.name: Maximiliano Guillermo

texts.es:
Don Maximiliano, un señor de 65 años de edad, muy trabajador dedicado a la agricultura en pequeño de maíz y pipián, reside en Jiquilisco departamento de Usulután, donde vive con su esposa quien se dedica a la venta de ropa, y sus hijos, Don Maximiliano tiene 30 años de dedicarse a la agricultura, y está en proceso de sembrar 4 manzanas de terreno, tres de maíz y una de pepino, este cultivo es la fuente de ingreso de don Maximiliano.
El Solicita un préstamo para la compra de insumos agrícolas como abono y fertilizantes, con esta compra tendrá lo necesario para producir el maíz y pepino de esta temporada de siembras.
El objetivo de él es cultivar las dos cosechas del años siguiente, para poder comercializarla a tiempo y ganar ingresos para su familia y solventar necesidades y gastos que siempre en cada hogar existen.
texts.en:
Maximiliano, age 65, is a hardworking man who farms corn and pipián squash. He lives in the Jiquilisco departament of Usulután with his wife, who sells clothing, and his children. Maximiliano has been farming for 30 years and is currently planting four plots of land: three plots of corn and one plot of cucumber. The harvest from these plots will be Maximiliano's only source of income. 

He is requesting a loan to purchase agricultural supplies, like organic and chemical fertilizers. With the fertilizer, Maximiliano will be able to obtain a good harvest this season. His goal is to farm both seasons in the next few years and sell the harvest at market to pay his family's living expenses.

loans.use: Purchase of organic and chemical fertilizers.

loans.name: And Liggueye Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité AND LIGGUEYE est créé depuis 2 ans et demi. Il est composé de 32 femmes provenant de quartiers différents mais qui nouent de bonne relations d'amitié. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de HERSENT2.

Madame DIABOU W. à l'extrême gauche de la photo et levant la main est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 46 ans. Elle est divorcée et mère de 07 enfants. Elle a aussi la charge d'un enfant qui lui est confié par des proches. 

Depuis 04 ans elle fait un petit commerce. Elle vend particulièrement des sandales et des habits. 

Son nouveau crédit lui permettra de renforcer légèrement son activité en augmentant son niveau d'approvisionnement.

Son objectif est de satisfaire les besoins de ses enfants: scolarité, nourriture, habillement etc.
texts.en:
he  “And Liggueye” solidarity group has been created two and a half years ago. It is composed of 32 women living in different districts but maintaining friendship ties. The group belongs to the Banc Villageois of Hersent2. 

Mrs. Diabou W., on the far left in the photo and raising her hand, is the group’s leader. She is 46 years old. She is divorced and the mother of 7. She also has another child in her, entrusted to her by relatives. She has had a small business for four years. She sells mainly sandals and clothing.
Her new loan will allow her to strengthen her business somewhat by increasing her stock. Her goal is to provide for her children’s needs: schooling, food, clothing etc.

loans.use: Growing her business

loans.name: Beatrice Wanjiru

texts.en:
Beatrice Wanjiru M. lives in Kariobangi estate. She is 43 years old and married with two children. She has been selling secondhand shoes at the busy Gikomba open-air market in Nairobi for eight years and earns a good income. 

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a member of KADET.  She is applying for her first loan of KES 80,000 from KADET. She plans to use the loan amount to buy seven bales of shoes, pay rent for the market stall and pay transport.

She plans to use the profit to pay school fees for her children, and add more stock of shoes. In the future she desires to grow her business.

loans.use: To buy shoes to sell and pay rent.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta is a 51-year old married woman who supports her family by operating a business venture: vegetable growing and vending. She lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2010 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her vegetable growing and vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 3,000. 

Julieta is borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she could fund her business operations. This will be her 3rd loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Julieta aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the  Dungganon way.  

About NWTF:  

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy bananas.

loans.name: Janice

texts.en:
