loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
B. Theresa is a trader who sells bags of rice; she also prepares a native food called 'wakye' for sale. She is married to a carpenter and has 3 children. She is asking for the loan to buy more bags of rice, vegetable oil, tin tomatoes and others.

She is asking for $252 as additional capital to buy the items.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy inventory.

loans.name: Agate

texts.en:
Ms. Agate A. is 31 years old and the married mother of two children. She lives and works in Adéta, a medium-sized town about 150 kilometers away from Lomé, the capital of Togo. Agate buys children's clothing and shoes in Lomé and then resells them in the central market of Adéta.

She is requesting this loan to buy more children's clothes so that she can increase the size of her business. She hopes to diversify her inventory as well. She hopes that this expansion will enable her to better provide for her family, send her children to school, and improve the quality of all of their lives.

loans.use: To buy more children's clothes

loans.name: Carmen Beatriz

texts.es:
My name is Carmen Beatriz C. B., currently I am in the business of selling typical clothing in the village of Cruz Blanca of San Juan Sacatepequez where I live.  It has been approximately four years since I came into the business of selling clothing.  At first I helped a woman sell her merchandise on commission.  At that time I worked at a vegetable packing plant and, since I had already acquired experience selling clothing, I started to invest part of my salary in selling sweaters.  Thereafter, I got married and had a daughter so I dedicated myself completely to the business which is why I saw the need to invest more capital in the business.  I now also sell local clothing such as guipiles, shirts, shawls, girdles and other products which my clients might request such as sandals.  Since I now have a fixed clientele, I deliver the clothing to my customers' homes or they stop by my home to make their purchases.  What I want to accomplish is to be able to invest more capital and to put a stall in San Juan Sacatepequz.  However, this requires a lot of capital which is why I want to increase my clientele to obtain this capital.  This will allow me to take advantage of the important upcoming holidays. 



 Translated from Spanish by Cindy M., Kiva Volunteer.



Soy Carmen Beatriz C. B., actualmente mi negocio es vender ropa típica en la aldea Cruz Blanca de San Juan Sacatepéquez, es donde yo vivo. 
Hace aproximadamente  cuatro años que inicie en el negocio de la venta de ropa, pero primero yo únicamente le ayudaba a una señora a vender su mercadería y ella me pagaba una comisión, en ese entonces yo tenia un trabajo en una empacadora de verduras y con el salario que tenia, como yo ya había adquirido experiencia en la venta de ropa empecé a invertir parte de mi salario para vender suéteres, pero después que me case y que tengo ya una nena, me dediqué totalmente al negocio, por eso vi la necesidad de invertir más capital ya que, ahora vendo cortes típicos, güipiles, blusas, rebozos, fajas, y alguna otra cosa que mis clientas me van solicitando, como sandalias.  Como ya cuento con clientes fijos, la ropa la entrego en las casas de ellas o ellas llegan  a mi casa para comprar, pero lo que quiero lograr es poder invertir más capital y poder poner un local en San Juan Sacatepéquez, pero eso requiere de mucho capital, por lo que quiero primero ganar más clientes obtener ese capital que necesito y aprovechar las fechas importantes más próximas para vender y que en un plazo no muy largo pueda poner mi local.

loans.use: Purchase and sale of typical clothing

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian is married with one child. She is 37 years old and she has been selling assorted soft drinks in her local town for 5 years now. Her town is very popular with tourists who visit the country and, therefore, the demand for drinks is high. Vivian wants to use the loan to buy more crates and cartons of drinks to increase her inventory and sales. She is a member of the group called God is Good. Members agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more crates of soft drinks

loans.name: Šerifa

texts.en:
Šerifa is a 47 year old woman living in Kotorsko, near the town of Doboj. She is a widow and has 4 children. Her oldest three are married, while the youngest lives with her and is in 8th grade in the local school. She receives her husband’s pension, which gives her about 300KM monthly. This 1,000KM loan will be her 5th loan with Zene za Zene.

Šerifa has been able to maintain an extensive business. She works in agriculture, growing corn & fruit and also raising chickens. She sells her fruit, vegetables, and eggs in the village, and makes jams & marmalade to sell as well. She is able to keep some of the food she grows to feed herself & her youngest child. For this loan, Šerifa is requesting 1000KM to buy seeds for growing corn and also to purchase fuel for her tractor.

loans.use: To buy seeds to grow corn, and fuel for her tractor

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia O. says that selling provisions and body cream is a lucrative business.  She is thirty-two years old and married with four children.  She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  She has been in this business of selling provisions and body cream for the past four years.  She needs the loan amount of $700 to buy more inventory to sell.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and body cream to sell

loans.name: Yawa

texts.fr: Yawa G. est âgée de 35 ans, mariée te mère de 3 enfants. Elle tient à Danyi, un village situé à environ 120 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise, un bar restaurant. Elle désire par ce crédit aménager son bar pour offrir un cadre plus accueillant à ses clients et aussi s’abonner à une société de livraison de boissons pour bénéficier des livraisons en gros.
texts.en:
Yawa G. is 35 years old, married, and the mother of three. She has a bar-restaurant in Danyi, a village located about 120 km from Lomé, the Togolese capital. She would like to use this loan to fix up her bar in order to offer a more welcoming atmosphere to her customers and also to join a beverages delivery company to benefit from wholesale deliveries.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To fix up her bar and also to supply it with beverages

loans.name: Víctor

texts.es:
El señor Victor A. nació en Concepción, vive con Rosana Ramírez hace mas de diez años con quien tuvo una hija llamada Jeny de 10 años.

Es comerciante y se dedica a la venta de artículos como agendas, bolígrafos, accesorios para teléfonos móviles entre otros.

Gracias al financiamiento de la Fundación pudo aumentar su nivel comercial y consecuentemente su ingreso familiar.

Desea el crédito para la compra de más mercaderías.
texts.en:
Mr. Victor A. was born in Concepción. He has lived with Rosana Ramírez for more than 10 years and they have a daughter named Jeny who is 10 years old. He is a salesman who works selling items like agendas, pens and mobile telephone accessories among other things. Thanks to the financing provided by the Foundation he has been able to increase his sales and consequently his family's income. He is requesting a loan to purchase more merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase electronic goods and items like flashlights, CDs, radios and mobile phone accessories

loans.name: Nadezhda

texts.en:
Nadezhda sells retail items (outer clothing, household items, etc.) in one of the local markets of Berdyansk, where she is originally from. Nadezhda is divorced and both of her kids are grown. She is well known in the marketplace where she has been running her business, for her respectful and honest approach to each client and her regular increases in stock. Her business has grown to a level when Nadezhda already has $800 in merchandise. Her income is about $650 a month.

Nadezhda is very accurate in her partnership relations with suppliers. She always weighs all pros and cons and makes all important decisions only after each of them is thought about thoroughly. She is full of enterprising ideas and ready to implement her business expansion plan. One thing she needs to make it happen is additional funding. Nadezhda is requesting a 3000 Grivna loan to increase her turnover capital. She is hoping to repay the current loan in 3 months.

loans.use: To increase turnover

loans.name: Freddy Bayardo

texts.es: El señor Freddy Bayardo A.  tiene la edad de 36 años habita en Reparto Juan Ramón Padilla, junto a su esposa, ellos no tiene hijos, la esposa de don Freddy trabaja como domestica en una casa particular, para ayudarle con los gastos de la casa. El señor tiene proyecto futuro para hacer su vivienda ya que ellos están en un cuarto que le dio su mamá de su suegra. Este señor trabaja como vendedor ambulante desde hace dos años, el solicita C$ 8,000.00 córdobas para comprar frutas y verduras el ya tiene un mercado definido el cual entrega su producto. La mayor dificultad es la falta de financiamiento.
texts.en:
Freddy Bayardo A. is 36 years old and lives with his wife in Reparto Juan Ramón Padilla. They do no have any children. To help with living expenses, Freddy’s wife works as a domestic in a private home. In the future Freddy hopes to get their own home, but for now they have a room given to them by his wife’s grandmother. He has worked as a street vendor for the past two years, and is requesting a loan of $425 (8,000 córdobas) in order to buy fruits and vegetables. As he already has a market for his produce, the major obstacle is the lack of funding.

Translated from Spanish by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Karina

texts.es: Karina tiene 31 años, vive con su esposo y sus 2 pequeños hijos. Tiene una tienda de abarrotes desde hace 3 años, con la que obtiene ingresos económicos para el sostenimiento de su hogar, ella contrata a una persona para la atención, debido a que ella es profesora y permanece en el colegio durante el día, lo que no le permite atender ella misma su tienda. Karina está ahora muy animada para hacer crecer su negocio y lograr convertirlo en un minimarket. Es la tercera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, y ha demostrado ser puntual en sus pagos. Karina solicita esta cantidad para invertirla netamente en mercadería no perecible para su bodega.
texts.en:
Karina is 31 years old and lives with her husband and their two small children. She has had a grocery store for three years and it provides extra income to maintain her family; because she is a teacher and spends all day at school, she employs a person to attend to the store.

Karina is very keen to expand the shop to convert it into a mini-mart. This is her third loan from MFP; she puntually repaid her previous loans.

Karina will use the entire amount of the loan to buy non-perishable goods for her store.

Translated from Spanish by John Rynne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise for a grocery store

loans.name: Alem Qaleen Baf Group

texts.en:
M. Alem is the group leader of the Alem Qaleen Baf group. There are three members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for his/her own business.

Shama and M. Alem want to take a loan for the business of carpet weaving. Palwasha wants to take a loan for her husband’s business. They all want to see progress in their businesses and to earn more money to support their families and solve their problems 

They say that these loans can be very useful because they provide a chance for poor entrepreneurs to expand their businesses.

loans.use: They all want to see progress in their business

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia M. is a 34-year-old woman. She is married and has two children, both of whom are in school. She lives with her family in Koforidua, a suburb of Offinso, in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Emelia is an achiever and a resourceful young woman. She loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living. 

For more than five years, Emelia has been selling fruits such as bananas and oranges by the side of the road in Koforidua. She treks to surrounding villages to purchase bananas and oranges from farmers.  Emelia buys unripe bananas in bulk and covers them with plantain leaves in the bush. When they are ripe, she picks them up to sell to her customers. For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to buy enough stock to make enough profit to support her family.  With the loan, she wants to purchase bananas and oranges in bulk, so she can scale up business growth. She believes the loan will enable her to earn more income to support her family. She wants to use part of the profit to support her children's education.
  
Emelia belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame yekese’ which means God is Great.

loans.use: To purchase bananas and oranges.

loans.name: Muyassarhon

texts.ru:
Ахмадова Муяссархон  1971 года рождения, замужем, имеет 4 детей. Первый кредит получила  прошлому году на животноводство. Дома содержит коров,  после откорма ее муж продает на рынке. Получившее молоко от коровы, также имеет хорошую прибыль, потому что идет на продажу, а также кисломолочные изделия. 
Муяссар сотрудничает с Микроинвест  1 год. Планирует продолжать сотрудничество.
texts.en:
Born in 1971, Muyassarhon A. is married and has 4 children. She received her first credit for animal husbandry last year. She raises cattle at home, and then, her husband sells them at a market. Milk and other dairy products also bring a good profit when these products are sold. Muyassarhon has been working with MicroInvest for 1 year and plans to continue the partnership.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of livestock and livestock feed

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Madame  Mariam   D.  est âgée de 51 ans,  veuve et mère de  5  enfants, elle vit dans une famille polygame avec  sa coépouse et leurs enfants au quartier Pelengana Nord de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant abandonné l’école prématurément, elle commença très tôt  les activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa mère qui commercialisait les céréales. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités, elle finit par opter pour le commerce d’habits, de chaussures, de couvertures et de draps de lit. Elle mène ce commerce depuis 15 ans et jouit d’une grande popularité et célébrité  dans le quartier.
Dans le souci de renforcer et  diversifier son activité, elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance avec qui elle est en relation depuis 30 mois. Après 3 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) et  2 prêts individuels tous correctement bien  remboursés, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel.
Elle  utilisera ce prêt pour acheter, 20 paires de couvertures et draps de lit, 10 paires de chaussures et 10 complets de pagnes brodés. 
Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako ou au Burkina Faso et effectue sa vente au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée  d’hommes et  de femmes.  
Avec ce prêt elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100. 000FCFA  lequel lui permettra de payer les frais de scolarité et de mutualité de ses enfants. 
Son ambition est de construire son terrain nu en usage d’habitation
texts.en:
Ms. Mariam D., age 51, is a widow and the mother of 5 children. She lives in a polygamous family with her co-wife and their children in the Pelengana Nord district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having abandoned school prematurely, she very soon started working to earn an income. She learned this from her mother, who used to market grain. After having done several kinds of work, she ended up choosing commerce in clothing, shoes, blankets, and bed sheets. She’s been in this business for 15 years and enjoys much popularity and fame in her area.

Concerned with bolstering and diversifying her business, she turned to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, which she has had an association with for 30 months. After 3 solidarity loans (group loans) and 2 individual loans, all correctly repaid, she is now on her third individual loan. She will use this loan to buy 20 sets of blankets and bed sheets, 10 pairs of shoes, and 10 outfits of embroidered pagnes. Supplies are gotten in Bamako or in Burkina Faso, and sales are made to customers composed of men and women, cash or credit accepted.

With this loan, she intends to realize a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will enable her to pay the school costs and insurance for her children. Her ambition is to clear a plot of land for living on.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
In 2002, Angela T. began growing cereals on four hectares of land. She grows corn, wheat, barley, and sunflower. She has a tractor to help her cultivate the soil. In addition to growing cereals, Angela also raises pigs and cattle. In 2007, she took a loan from Microinvest for working capital. She repaid that loan entirely. 

Angela is now asking for a loan so she can buy seedlings, fuel, and fertilizer. She plans to purchase watermelon seedlings because a part of her land is of a lower quality, but is very good for watermelons.

loans.use: To buy  buy seedlings, fuel, and fertilizer

loans.name: Monica's Group

texts.en: Monica B., the married mother of three who also cares for one orphan, is the representative of Atakola group in Jinja.  Monica has a grocery store that operates on a modest scale. When she joined her lending group, she had had the business for only one year, but since then has used her loans to increase the stock. As a result, she has been able to pay school fees for her children with the help of her husband as well as increase her business’s capital. She is requesting a new loan to help with restocking her shop with more products.

loans.use: Restocking her shop with more products.

loans.name: Yehia

texts.en:
Yehia is a 30-year-old man who lives in Saida in southern Lebanon. Yehia has owned a snack shop for seventeen years.  He sells all types of sandwiches. Yehia is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his snack shop. This is the first time that Yehia has requested a loan.

Yehia treats his clients well and is known for his good sandwiches. His clients are his friends, neighbors, and others in the local area.  When he first started his business, Yehia had to face much competition.  In the future, he plans on expanding his snack shop by opening a restaurant.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his snack shop.

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly Y., 47, is married with two children and resides in Phnom Penh city. She sells soup and rice to earn approximately US$5 profit every day. Her husband sells ice cream and makes US$6 per day. Their two children also sell ice cream. Ly Y. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to reinvest in her soup and rice shop. She will increase the amount of rice she sells. (Ly was not available so her husband is pictured instead).

loans.use: To reinvest in her soup and rice shop.

loans.name: Tupendane  B Group

texts.en:
Aziza L., age 38, is married. Her two children are aged 17 and 20 years. She has a salon business, which she started 4 years ago. She works daily from 8am until 8pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around $154. 

This will be Aziza’s seventh loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to open the salon business. She used to sell clothes and has repaid the loans successfully. She hopes for a seventh loan to help to expand both businesses. 
	
Aziza will share this loan with her loan group, Tupendane B, which totals  16 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Aziza is in the middle, front row, in a black sleeveless blouse.

loans.use: To buy more salon equipment.

loans.name: Bokk Xalaat Group

texts.fr:
LE GROUPEMENT BOKK XALAAT  est un groupe composé de cinq femmes tres dynamiques qui font du petit commerce et habitent au quartier concorde
elles font des activités génératrices de revenu telles que la restauration,la vente de tissus ,de jus et de parfum;avec le pret qu'elles sollicitent ,elles envisagent d'augmenter leur fonds de roulement
texts.en:
The group BOKK XALAAT is composed of 5 energetic women who are involved in petty trading and live in the Concorde neighborhood.

They make a living selling cooked food, cloth, juice, perfume, etc. With the loan that they are requesting, they plan to add to their working capital.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: adding to their working capital

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma M. tills a 1.75 hectare rice field in Sto. Nino, South Cotabato. She is 44 years old and has one child. She started working on the farm in 1989. She needs additional capital to run her business, so she joined the CEVI credit program.

She is requesting another loan of Php 12,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizers and chemicals.

CEVI helps her grow her business even more. She can get loans, training and insurance coverage through CEVI.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma D. is from the town of Salimpuno, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 25 years old. Alma is married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Alma plants and harvests cassava for sale. Alma has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,800 PHP a month.

In 2008, Alma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and to increase her ability to engage in business activities. Alma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC.

Alma is now requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be Alma's second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr: Khady F. est une femme mariée de 45 ans, mère de 6 enfants. Elle vend des jus de fruits et de la glace. Les revenus générés lui permettent de mieux améliorer les conditions de vie, de santé et de scolarité de sa famille.

loans.use: Vente de glace et de jus de fruits

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en: Margarita strives very hard in her sales businesses so she can improve her family’s economic condition. She is married to Johny and they are blessed with one child named Jomar.  She hopes to earn enough income to finance the education of her son until he earns a college degree.  In this regard, she requests a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP5000 for her fruit and vegetable business. Her husband Johny helps her with the business by maintaining their small fruits and vegetable farm.  Helping each other is very necessary and Margarita is thankful for having a husband like Johny. Margarita also sells cooked foods and snacks inside the school campus, and she also sells charcoal.  Her businesses are very beneficial to them.  She wants to continue improving her businesses and hopes that her loan request will be approved.

loans.use: To expand her sales businesses.

loans.name: Djikiya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djikiya sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 30 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Konobougou, sous préfecture de Baroueli, Région de Ségou, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et  exercent comme activité le petit commerce d’articles divers. Ces femmes ont intégrés  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. Elles sont à leur septième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, 15 sacs de céréales et une grande quantité d’autres articles divers tels que les fruits, les légumes et les poulets au marché de Konobougou et environnants et sont revendus sur place à Konobougou à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 50.000FCFA par mois, qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activés. 
Elles  ambitionnent de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant d’autres activités génératrices de revenus.

loans.use: Achat d’articles divers.

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.en:
This is Ernestina. She is 45 years-old and single with two children. Ernestina is part of a communal bank consisting of eleven neighbors who live in the San Sebastián district of Cusco. The group is called Maria Auxilladora, named after the Virgin of Peru. Ernestina is a native of Cusco.

Ernestina is a craftsperson and artist. From her home studio, she paints and makes lamps out of iron. With the loan, she will buy materials to continue her artistic endeavors.

Ernestina appreciates and thanks you for the loan and promises to make the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: To buy materials for painting and lamp making.

loans.name: Bembeya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Bembeya est composé de quatre femmes (une veuve et  trois mariées) vivant dans de grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans,  4 enfants et habitent  dans le quartier Djaka (Kirango)  de Markala (4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage, d’amitié et de voisinage et ont une activité génératrice de revenu portant essentiellement sur la vente du poisson sous toutes ses formes.
Dans le souci de mieux rentabiliser leurs activités, elles décidèrent d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Le groupe Bembeya est à son 5ème prêt solidaire après avoir correctement remboursé les quatre prêts précédents.
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 16 paniers de poisson frais et 40 barres  de glace (fournies par les transporteurs venant de Bamako). Elles s’approvisionnent  en poissons frais sur place au bord du fleuve Niger, qui est trié dont une  partie est séchée (soit sur du gravier soit sur de la paille ou sur des « seccos »). Le poisson se vend sous toutes ses formes : les poissons frais se vendent sur place au bord du fleuve Niger,  à Kirango et à Diamarabougou Markala parfois en ambulant dans les quartiers, le frais conservé dans de la glace se vend à Ségou (au marché château) et  Bamako,  le poisson séché dont une partie est conservée jusqu’à la décrue et en l’hivernage où elles gagnent plus d’argent  est surtout vendu à Dougabougou, Siribala, Niono, Shango, Boussin et à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou. Les ventes se font généralement au comptant à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 22.300 FCFA qui servira à satisfaire les petits besoins familiaux (l’habillement, savon, pétrole) et à participer aux évènements sociaux (baptême, mariage et décès). 
Leur ambition est  d’avoir une concession à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The group named Bembeya is made up of four women (one is a widow and three are married). They live with large traditional families. On average they are 39 years old and have 4 children. They live in the Djaka (Kirango) district of Markala (the 4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They know each other through family, by marriage, and through friends and neighbors. They all carry out the same type of revenue-generating business selling fish, in all its forms.

In hopes of improving their business, they decided to approach the Soro Yiriwaso program (Kiva Field Partner). The Bembeya group are currently on their fifth loan, after having repaid the four previous loans on time.

This loan will be used to purchase 16 baskets of fresh fish, 40 blocks of ice (brought in by the transports coming in from Bamako). They buy their fresh fish along the Niger River, one part of which is separated to be dried (either on gravel stones, on hay, or on ‘seccos’). The fish is sold in various forms: fresh fish are sold along the Niger River, in Kirango and in Diamarabougou Markala, sometimes traveling to various districts. The fresh fish is preserved with ice and it is sold in Segou (at the Chateau market) and in Bamako. The dried fish, part of which is set aside to be sold during the shortages and winter months to earn greater revenues, is sold primarily in Dougabougou, Siribala, Niono, Shango, Boussin and in the weekly fairs at Segou. The sales are usually completed in cash and the clientele is the general public

They hope to earn average monthly revenues of 22.300 FCFA that will help to provide for the needs of their family (clothing, soap, fuel) and to participate in social events (baptisms, weddings, and funerals).

Their hope is to have a house.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fish.

loans.name: Bolotshi Plus Group

texts.fr:
Ngele B. 49 ans, est dirigeante d’une Banque communautaire dénommée « Bolotshi Plus » constituée solidairement de 31 membres avec un objectif commun de développer leurs petites affaires par des microcrédits reçus des prêteurs du monde à travers Kiva et l’IMF HOPE RDC.
Ngele a comme activité principale, la vente des pagnes wax anglaises. Elle l’a commencée depuis 2004 avec un capital initial de $20 et a acquit au fil des années une expérience solide dans ce petit commerce qui lui rapporte aujourd’hui un bénéfice de plus ou moins $120 par semaine. Le prochain prêt lui permettra d’acheter une douzaine de pagnes à revendre et diversifier l’affaire en achetant des articles divers recherchés dans son milieu. Son rêve est d’ouvrir une boutique générale pour répondre aux besoins de ses clients dans son quartier. Ngele est une cliente fidèle qui a reçu 5 fois les crédits de l’IMF HOPE RDC et les a tous correctement remboursés. Elle est veuve avec 3 enfants âgés de 10 à 16 ans. Tous vont à l’école. Ngele et ses enfants habitent dans une zone montagneuse située à l’ouest de la ville de Kinshasa.
texts.en:
Ngele B., aged 49, is the manager of a communal bank named "Bolotshi Plus", which is established in solidarity with 31 members with the common objective of developing their small businesses by using micro-loans received from world lenders via Kiva and the micro-finance institution HOPE RDC.  Ngele's principal business involves selling Wax Anglaise pagnes (colorful West African cloth).  She started this business in 2004 with $20 in initial capital.  She has acquired over the years some solid experience in this small-scale commerce, which now brings in $120 a week in profit, more or less.  The next loan will enable her to buy a dozen lengths of pagnes to sell and to diversify her business by buying various goods in demand in her area.  Her dream is to open a general store to respond to the needs of her customers in her district.  Ngele is a loyal client who has received a loan from HOPE RDC five times, and she repaid all of them properly.  She is a widow with three children, ages 10 to 16 years.  All of them go to school.  She and her children live in a mountainous area located west of the city of Kinshasa.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a dozen lengths of pagne cloth for resale with the gaol of  growing her income

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein is a 19-year-old single man living with his parents and three brothers. He has been working as an electrician since 2006 to earn income to satisfy, in collaboration with his father and brothers, the needs of the family.

Today, Hussein is asking to borrow $1,200 to buy a car that will facilitate his business movements and enable him to be available upon his clients’ request.

loans.use: To buy a car for his business

loans.name: Lach

texts.en: Lach N. is a villager living in the rural area of Battambang province. She was married for many years and blessed with three children, who are married and no longer living at home. To earn a living, Lach N. owns a hand-cart that she uses to hawk, selling cakes and boiled corn to the people around her district.  She is usually able to generate about $5 of income a day. To help respond to the family’s needs, her husband runs a taxi service. Recently, he was unable to fulfill his customer’s requirements because his old motorcycle has broken down. Therefore, Lach N. applied for a loan to buy a new motorcycle to replace a broken one.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle to replace a broken one

loans.name: Lida

texts.en:
Lida B.'s main source of income comes from raising hogs to sell in her community. Lida is a 33-year-old married woman from the village of Minlasag. Lida has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2007, Lida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Lida has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Lida is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed, medicine and additional hogs. This will be her 5th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feed and medicine for raising hogs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Selling generic medications

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William is 48 years old and married. He has with five children, ages 26, 25, 23, 20, and 12. Four of the children are currently attending school. He is a farmer in the Kitale Region of Western Kenya. He's been farming for 15 years and sells eggs and poultry at the local market. He says that the main challenge to his business is the spread of disease among his stock of chickens, which can cause a lot of losses.

William has requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 46800 to purchase a dairy cow. He says that the extra income from this loan will help him provide for his family's basic needs. In the future, he would like to be a major supplier of his produce in his hometown market and beyond.

William also added that he is thankful for Juhudi Kilimo's loan because he is now economically empowered.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Mujeres Progresando Group

texts.es:
El comité “Mujeres Progresando”  está conformada por 17 integrantes,en la ciudad de Mariano Roque Alonso. Todas las integrantes del comité se encuentran desarrollando sus actividades con mucho esfuerzo y empeño.
Este comité  se encuentra en pleno desarrollo con mucho trabajo para llevar a cabo todos los objetivos de manera integral para todas.
Se pudo hablar con la  Sra . Mirian A.  posee un pequeño puesto de venta de ropa en el centro de la ciudad, ella surte sus mercaderías del  mercado de Asunción donde viaja cada semana para abastecerse de sus mercaderías. Ella vende ademas jugos naturales, tiene clientela formadas con el ingreso que ella lo realiza día a día ayuda al marido para la alimentación de la familia..
Ademas ella posee un objetivo la de mejorar y ampliar su pequeño negocio para  ello piensa trabajar mucho con el comité y así lograr su propósito.
A continuación se presentan las actividades aque se dedica cada integrante de los comite.
1
Mirian A.
Ventas de Ropas
2
Delia O.
Manicurista
3
Edith V.
Ventas de Cosmeticos
4
Eva R.
Ventas de Ropas
5
Mirian R.
Ventas de Ropas
6

texts.en:
The group “Mujeres Progresando” is formed by 17 members in the city of Mariano Roque Alonso. All of the members are developing their activities with a lot of effort and perseverance. This group is in full swing with a lot of work to do to complete all of their objectives in a comprehensive manner. Mirian A. has a small stand where she sells clothing in the center of the city. She stocks her store with merchandise from Asunción where she travels each week to buy merchandise, and she also sells natural juices. She has regular customers. With the income that she gets from this activity each day she helps her husband feed her family. Her goal is to improve and expand her small business. To do this she has been working with the group, and in this way she hopes to achieve her goal. Below the activities of each other member of the group are presented: 1 Mirian A. clothing sales 2 Delia O. Manicurist 3 Edith V. cosmetics sales 4 Eva R. clothing sales 5 Mirian R. clothing sales 6 Celsa P. the sale of meals 7 Perla L. cosmetics sales 8 Mercedes Carismo hairdresser 9 Maria Sixta D. the sale of cleaning products 10 Marcelina M. ice cream sales 11 Lucia D. cosmetics sales 12 Monica M. the sale of sewing supplies 13 Augusta P. clothing sales 14 Lourdes Segovia cosmetics sales 15 Margarita Gonzalez bread sales 16 Guillermina F. clothing sales 17 Meliza C. telephone operator

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy uniforms of all types for primary and secondary students, shirts, pants and skirts.

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Awa F. est une femme mariée de 48 ans mère de 7 enfants. Elle s’active dans le commerce d’huile d’arachide et en même temps fait de l’embauche bovine. Les revenus générés par son activité lui permettront de mieux améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Awa F. is a married woman who is 48 years old and has seven children. She is active in the peanut oil business and at the same time beef fattening. The revenues generated by her activities will allow her to improve her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To carry out beef fattening and peanut oil business

loans.name: Women Of Progress Group

texts.en: For 12 years, Joeana D. has been selling dried fish at the Red Light market in Paynesville, Liberia. She is 40 years old, married, and has seven children, age 2 to 22 years old. Joeana also cares for a sibling. She did not have the opportunity to go to school because her parents refused to send her. Joeana sells good quality dried fish and and talks to her customers in a nice manner which keeps them returning. Joeana plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar (LRD) portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more fish. Her goal is to expand sales to other markets within Paynesville. Joeana is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "Women of Progress". In the photo that accompanies this profile, Joeana is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, this non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more fish

loans.name: Srey You

texts.en:
Ms. Srey You H. was born in 1981 and she lives in Pou Khvet village in Takeo province. She is single and lives with a family member.

Ms. Srey You H. owns a general store in the village. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it but she does not have enough money to do this. Thus, in order to improve her family’s living conditions, Ms. Srey You H. decided to ask for a loan to buy gasoline to sell.

loans.use: To buy gasoline to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Production and sale of fritters

loans.name: Nere-An

texts.en:
Nere-an V. is a 29-year-old married woman who supports her family by owning a general store. She lives in Magsaysay, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental with her husband and their three children who are between 2 and 6 years old.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000.

Nere-an is now borrowing PHP 25,000 so that she can expand her general store. This will be her 7th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 21,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Nere-an aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

In the picture you can see Nere-an with her husband.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital to expand her general store

loans.name: Pheang's Group

texts.en: This group loan consists of  four people living in Prey Chambak village in Takeo province. They will each use their share of the loan for different purposes to improve their businesses. All the members have  selected Miss Pheang T. as group leader. She was born in 1968. She is a weaver and a silk cloth seller. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Miss Pheang T. is applying for a loan to buy more silk cloth to resell. She is single and lives with members of her household.

loans.use: To buy more silk cloth to resell

loans.name: Soy

texts.en: Soy C., 28, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. C. raises pigs at home for an income of USD 4 per day. Her husband produces rice wine, earning an income of about USD 4 per day. C. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a new motorbike to transport rice wine to sell.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. C. and her husband appear in the photograph at their place where they produce rice wine.

loans.use: buy a motorbike to transport their rice wine

loans.name: María Isabel

texts.es: María Isabel P. O. de 48 años de edad, vive junto a su única hija de 16 años de edad, con quien vive en el municipio de Lourdes Colón. María posee un comedor llamado Karen, el cual esta ubicado en su casa de habitación, en donde ha trabajado durante 14 años, haciendo desayunos y al almuerzos, los cuales en un principio únicamente vendía con sus vecinos, pero que en la actualidad vende incluso con motoristas del transporte público, lo cual le ha permitido incrementar sus ventas y así mismo ser más conocida en el lugar, María lo que necesita es poder incrementar su materia prima para poder atender a más clientes, es por esto que ella solicita un préstamo a Integral, por medio del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad de verduras, granos básicos, fruta, jugos, sodas, todo lo necesario para poder atender mejor a sus clientes y así mismo atender a más clientes. Ella desea mucho poder aprovechar al máximo esta situación, debido a que es la única forma en la cual se gana la vida, y la cual le ha permitido poder sostener a su hija durante mucho tiempo, ya que ella es madre soltera, y es la única que vela por el bienestar de su hogar y el de su hija.
texts.en:
María Isabel P. O., age 48, lives with her only daughter who is 16 years old. They live in the Lourdes Colón municipality. María has a diner named Karen, which is located in her house. She has worked there for 14 years making breakfasts and lunches. At first she only sold the meals to her neighbors. But now she sells to public transportation motorists. This has allowed her to increase her sales and become more well-known in her area. María needs to be able to increase her raw materials in order to be able to wait on more customers. That is why she is requesting a loan from Integral. She will use the loan to buy a greater quantity of vegetables, basic grains, fruit, juices, sodas, and everything that is needed to be able to better tend to her customers. She will also be able to take care of more customers. She very much wishes to be able to take advantage to the maximum of this situation. This is because it is the only way that she earns a living. It has allowed her to be able to support her daughter for a long time. She is a single mother, and she is the only one that watches out for her home and her daughter’s well-being.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy raw materials to make food

location.town: Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María de 58 años, vive en la Perimetral de Guayaquil (zona periurbana, llamada la Isla Trinitaria porque esta rodeada de un estero). Ella tiene un puesto de venta de ropa, desde hace años. 

Trabajo como vendedora de artesanías en un puesto de en el centro, pero como tenia pocos ingresos ya que se quedo viuda con dos hijos comenzó a vender ropa, después que paso un tiempo de haber muerto su esposo pudo conseguir un puesto en el mercado para vender ropa. Trabaja desde las 07h00am hasta las 14h00. 

Para poder continuar con su negocio ella quiere comprar con el préstamo ropa y artesanías, en el futuro quiere tener un local propio y terminar de construir su vivienda.
texts.en:
María, 58, lives along Guayaquil’s beltway (a periurban area called Isla Trinitaria because it’s surrounded by an estuary). She has had a clothing sales booth for several years. At one time she worked selling crafts in a stand downtown but because income was low and she was widowed with two children to support she started to sell clothing. Some time after her husband’s death she was able to get a stand in the market to sell her clothing. She is open for business from 7am until 2pm. To continue with her business she needs funds to buy clothing and crafts. In the future, she’d like to own her own locale and finish building her house

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For clothing and crafts.

loans.name: Sargsyan

texts.en:
M. Sargsyan lives in the village of Pokr Mantash in the Shirak region.  She is married and very proud of her two sons (23 and 27 years old).  M. has been engaged in cattle breeding for the past 18 years and with the income from her business supports her family.  She also helps her relatives living in Artik with the proceeds of her business. 

 M. has chosen to expand her business and is seeking a loan to purchase additional calves.  She expects the family income to increase by 30% with the business loan.  M. was born in Pokr Mantash and would like to continue living in her village.  By growing her business she hopes to improve the future of her family.

loans.use: purchase additional calves

loans.name: Tavakkal

texts.en:
Tavakkal is 44 years old and he is the father of two children. His wife is a housekeeper and she supports him in everything he does. Tavakkal is a hard working person and he has been providing taxi services for more than 3 years. The most important goal to him is for his children to finish school so that they may have a bright future. Tavakkal wishes to keep his taxi business growing. For the expansion of this taxi business, he needs to have his working tools in good working order. Tavakkal needs to buy spare parts to improve the condition of his taxi and that is why he is requesting a loan. Thanks to this work, Tavakkal has been able to stabilize his quality of life.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Towards purchasing spare parts for repairing his car.

loans.name: Elda

texts.en: Elda A. is from the village of Catohugan, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 56 years old and is married with six adult children. Elda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Elda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Elda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Toin

texts.en:
Toin S., 38, is married and resides with her husband in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. She raises livestock at home for an income of $5 per day. Her husband is a police officer, earning an income of $5 per day.  

S. is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase more animal food to feed the chickens. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy animal food to feed the chickens

loans.name: Molmol

texts.en:
Molmol T.  lives in Osh city, south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 46, married, and has three children. Molmol graduated from medical college as a nurse and devoted 15 years of practical experience to helping her patients to overcome their diseases. 

In 1995, when Molmol was expecting a baby, her husband lost his job. Those times became a period of living in the pinch of poverty for her family. But Molmol didn’t give up and decided to start her own business reselling linens, fabrics and tablecloths, using her initial capital of 10,000 KGS.

In spite of many the highs and lows in her activity, Molmol managed to broaden her business by purchasing two small shops and achieved success. These activities led her to obtain loans from “Bai Tushum and Partners”, which were repaid without any delays. Molmol’s husband, who was infected by her enthusiasm, became the main helper and strong supporter in the business. 

But in June 2010, when violent clashes caused by deposed the political regime broke out in Osh, Molmol lost her business. Her shops were robbed and looted. However, Molmol  is ready to resume her lost business and continue to work. For this reason, Molmol is applying for a loan of 135,000 KGS, which she needs to restart her activity. She plans to purchase home products for resale at the local market. With the revenue from this loan, Molmol plans to give a good education to her daughter, because she believes that educated youth can move their motherland forward. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase goods for resale

loans.name: El Hadji Dial Mbaye

texts.fr: Monsieur El Hadji Dial Mbaye S. est âgé de 35 ans. Il habite dans la localité de Yoff. Il est marié sans enfant. Monsieur S. est enseignant de fonction depuis 2005 dans une école à Yoff. Suite aux conseils  de son oncle qui était directeur dans les temps il a opté pour l’enseignement. Ceci l’a beaucoup intéressé  parce qu’il  éprouve  un grand plaisir à inculquer le savoir aux enfants. Mais parallèlement  il mène une activité de commerce et de vente d’habits pour enfants au marché  de Yoff ou il gère  une boutique pendant les vacances.  Pendant l’année scolaire  la boutique est confiée  à une de ses cousines et ainsi il se charge d’assurer la supervision. Il est membre  de la caisse  de Yoff depuis aout 2006.Il n’a jamais sollicité de crédit au sein de l’institution. Il emprunte 250 000 frs pour acheter des habits pour enfants qui seront destinés a la vente et ainsi renforcer son stock de marchandises dans sa cantine. Le but visé par monsieur S. est d’accroitre ses revenus et d’améliorer les  conditions  de vie sociale de sa famille.
texts.en: Mr. El Hadji Dial Mbaye S. is 35 years old. He lives in the Yoff township. He is married without children. Mr. S. has been employed as a teacher in a Yoff school since 2005. Following the advice of his uncle, who was the school principal at that time, he decided to go into teaching. This work attracted him because he really enjoys imparting knowledge to children. In addition, he also sells children’s clothing at the Yoff market, where he manages a store during school vacations. During the school year, the store is entrusted to a cousin, and he oversees its operation. He joined the Yoff mutual fund in August 2006. He never requested a loan before. He is borrowing 250,000 West African francs now in order to purchase children’s clothing for resale, increasing his merchandise stock. His goal is to increase his revenues and to improve the social conditions of his family.

loans.use: Bolstering working capital

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena has a sari-sari store business. Her husband’s support of this business is Lorena’s inspiration to persevere through the test of poverty to grow her business despite her circumstances. Sari-sari stores basically sell small quantities of various foodstuffs, groceries and beverages. “Sari” is a native word for variety. These small stores are either attached to the owner’s house or in a small native cottage not far from the owner’s home. Such stores are convenient for people in the barangay (village) who live far from the marketplace or town.
This kind of business has brought pleasure to Lorena’s family. With its profits, she has been able to support her family’s need. Being a good mother, Lorena always wanted to support her three children in whatever career they would choose to better their personal life. Aside from Lorena’s variety store business financed by the loan she received from Kiva partner, ASHI, she also has a buy and sell business, which is her way of saving profits to support her family's needs, especially her children’s education until college. With this in mind, Lorena is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders to purchase grocery items for her store and support her buy and sell business. This loan will help her businesses grow and make more profit, which will enable her to support her ambitions in life.
Lorena has been an ASHI member since 2004. Her family is very thankful that she has an opportunity to improve her living conditions through the income of her two businesses, both of which she has established with the support of previous loans. Her long-term goals are to have passenger jeepney (small bus) for added income, expand to a fully fledged grocery store, and give her children a better future. These dreams fuel her to continue her dedication to her ventures.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Rosibel Maria

texts.es: Rosibel Maria tiene 59 años, su actividad es la venta de frijoles, tortillas y tamales. Es una persona muy reconocida por su trabajo, por lo que siempre le ha gustado sacar a su familia adelante. Esta no es la primera vez que solicita créditos, pues la experiencia que ha obtenido ha sido muy gratificante para ella y su negocio. Este crédito es para comprar maíz, leña y frijoles. Siempre se ha preocupado por brindar un buen servicio y buena calidad en sus productos.
texts.en: Rosibel Maria is 59 years old.  She sells beans, tortillas and tamales.  She is a very well-known person because of her work and has always liked to help her family get ahead.  This is not the first time that she has requested a loan.  The experience that she has gained has been very rewarding for her and her business.  This loan will be used to buy corn, firewood and beans.  She has always made sure that she provides a good service and good quality products.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Rufino

texts.en:
Rufino M. is from the town of Trinidad. He is 59 years old. Rufino is married and has four children. His eldest child is 29 years old and the youngest is 15. Rufino operates "habal-habal" (motorcycle) transport services. He works daily. Rufino is also an operator of a rice mill. He says his income from it also helps in their daily needs. Rufino works hard to build his transportation business.

Rufino joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rufino has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Rufino is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Miguelita

texts.en:
Miguelita D. is a 34-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating one business venture: fishing/fish vending  business.  She lives in Calma, Brgy. Malbago, Daanbantayan, Cebu.  She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2010 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts.  

By working hard in her fishing / fish Vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000.  Miguelita is now borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can purchase more fishing gear and equipment. This will be her 2nd loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 3,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Miguelita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way.  

About NWTF: 

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of fishing gear and equipment

loans.name: Beatriz Adelina

texts.es:
Beatriz Adelina O. M. tiene 39 años de edad, Vive en Unión Libre vive con el compañero y con los hijos,  vive en el cantón de Ventanas Provincia los Ríos. Tiene 3 hijos.

Los miembros de la V.R.C. NUEVO HORIZONTE se encuentra ubicada En el recinto Cachel y Grande, perteneciente al cantón Ventanas, esta ventanilla se dedica a labores agrícolas de ciclo corto siembra de maíz, arroz, fréjol gandul., esta actividad llevan mucho tiempo haciéndolo.
  
Beatriz Adelina se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, arroz, fréjol gandul. Compra sus productos en el Agro Karlyta y vende su producto en la comercial Olivo.

Solicita el crédito para la comprar de insumos agrícolas y fertilizantes para el cultivo de maíz, arroz, fréjol gandul. Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentan desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es poder comprar un terreno.

Le gusta realizar los quehaceres domésticos.
texts.en:
Beatriz Adelina O. M. is 39 years old.  She is in a common-law marriage and lives with her partner and their children.  They live in the canton of Ventanas in Los Ríos province.  She has three children.

The members of the "Nuevo Horizonte" ["New Horizon"] Communal Bank are based in the Cachel y Grande precinct, which is part of the canton of Ventanas. The members of this communal bank work in short-cycle agriculture, growing corn, rice, and pigeon peas. They have all been doing this for a long time.
  
Beatriz Adelina works in agriculture.  She grows corn, rice, and pigeon peas.  She buys products at Agro Karlyta and sells what she produces at the Olivo market.

She is requesting this loan to buy agricultural supplies and fertilizers for growing corn, rice, and pigeon peas.  The economic support provided by this loan will help her to meet her needs.  She faces challenges like insect plagues and plant illnesses, as well as variations in the climate. Her dream is to be able to buy a piece of land.

She enjoys doing household chores.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies and fertilizers

loans.name: Silverio

texts.es:
Silverio tiene 40 años, es un hombre muy sencillo y trabajador, vive en su casa propia junto a sus 4 hijos, y lo que más desea es brindarles un mejor futuro.

El cultivo de café, plátano y palta, es la actividad a la que se dedica Silverio, todos los días desde muy temprano sale a trabajar a sus chacras, con el único fin de esforzarse mucho para que sus cultivos tengan muy buena calidad.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es cultivar, lleva 20 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es fumigar sus tierras, ya que los químicos son muy peligrosos. Con el tiempo, espera sembrar más y así tener una mejor producción.

Este es el segundo préstamo de Silverio con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas puntualmente si quiere acceder a otro préstamo. En su banco comunal es un socio muy cumplido y activo.
Con los dos mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará más abono e insecticidas para sus cultivos.
texts.en:
Silverio is 40 years old.  He is a very humble and hard-working man who lives in his own home together with his 4 children.  What he wants more than anything is to offer them a better future.

Silverio grows coffee, bananas and avocados.  Very early every day he goes out to work on his land with the sole aim of working hard so that he produces very good-quality crops.  What he most likes about his work is cultivating his land.  He has been in this business for 20 years and he considers the most difficult part of his work to be spraying his land since the chemicals are very dangerous.  Over time, he hopes to sow more crops and thereby improve his production.

This is Silverio's second loan with MFP.  He knows that he must make his repayments punctually if he wants to access another loan.  He is a very punctual and active member of his community bank.  Silverio plans to use the 2,000 Peruvian soles he has requested to buy more manure and insecticides for his crops.

loans.use: To buy manure and insecticides

loans.name: Paulette

texts.en:
Paulette is a mother of four children; the eldest is 7 years while the youngest is 11 months. Paulette has a store in which she sells soap, Vaseline, sugar and rice. 

Paulette is requesting a loan in order to buy more sugar, soap, Vaseline and rice in order to fill her store and hence make more profits. She is planning to buy more items with the profits she hopes to make.

loans.use: To buy sugar, soap and Vaseline

loans.name: Veang

texts.en:
Veang T., 32, is married to Hung, 35. She and has given birth to four children, all of whom are still young. 

Veang T. is a skilled manicurist and she has run a service of door to door nail decoration in the neighborhood since 2005. She earns a good profit. 

Her husband has been selling meatballs and other snack food for over five years. He runs his business by using a motorbike connected with a cart. Unluckily, his existing motorbike breaks so often that he spends a lot of money repairing it. To deal with this problem, Veang T. would like to request a loan for her husband to purchase a motorcycle to replace the broken one.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to transport products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more beauty products for her business.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter, 71, is married with two children, ages 26 and 42 years old. He has been practicing mixed farming for 22 years in Kitale town, western Kenya. He is currently producing milk which he sells to local restaurants and households. He also employs 3 farmhands. He is a retired civil servant hence depends on his pension to cater for the basic needs of his family.

He has requested a loan of 40,000 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase artificial insemination equipment for storing semen. He says that the profits from this business will assist him in paying school fees for his three grandchildren who are currently attending school. He says that he would like to own all kinds of artificial insemination equipment in future, acquire three motorcycles and employ three employees to enhance his profession.

He further comments that the cost of artificial insemination inputs is expensive hence farmers prefer to use the traditional bulls to service their animals.

loans.use: To purchase artificial insemination equipment.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine  N. lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has 6 children, all of whom are in school. She also has a business of selling bananas. She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Catherine sells her products at the market, by means of wholesale/retail. Catherine has requested a loan of 500000 Shillings Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas.

The main business challenges for Catherine include thieves and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholeasle only. Catherine lives in a home that she rents; she doesn't have access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include paying utility bills, rent,school fees, and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Trương

texts.en:
U. Trương Thị (20203050009) is a 24-year-old woman who lives in the town of Huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  She is married and has 3 school-aged children.  To make a living, U. owns and operates a furniture-making business in the manufacturing sector.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members.  U. has been engaged in this business for more than 4 years and earns approximately 6,000,000 Vietnamese dong (VND) a month from business activities.

U. joined SEDA in 2009 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  U. has successfully repaid a previous SEDA loan of 6,944,000 VND, which was used to purchase raw materials to expand her product offerings.  U. is now requesting a new loan of 8,736,000 VND, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital.  This will be her 3rd loan from SEDA.  U. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for its Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

U. Trương Thị (20203050009) là 24 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 3 trẻ ở độ tuổi đi học.  Để kiếm sống, U. Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh.  Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ sản xuất & bán trang thiết bị gia dụng thông thường cho các doanh nghiệp và người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  U. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 4 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, U. kiếm được khoảng 6.000.000 VND một tháng.

Vào 2009, U. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  U. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua ngU. liệu thô bổ sung để mở rộng việc giới thiệu sản phẩm.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.736.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua thêm hàng hóa tồn kho & vốn lưu động.  Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  U. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh cải thiện điều kiện sống chung của gia đình người vay.

Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase wood as material

loans.name: Jean Paul

texts.en: Jean Paul is 28 years old. He has two children, a one-month-old and a three-year-old. Jean Paul’s wife sells different items, while he owns a shop carrying items such as cooking oil, soap, salt, and rice. This business has enabled Jean Paul to meet his family's needs and build up some savings as well. Jean Paul is requesting a loan to buy more items to fill his store and make more profits. He plans to collect more savings and open up a wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: to buy more inventory

loans.name: Ami

texts.fr: Agée de 31 ans, cette jeune dame est mariée à un pasteur et est mère de 03 enfants. Elle s’est lancée dans la vente de produits cosmétiques depuis 2007.elle s’approvisionne sur place et revend de manière ambulante .ce prêt servira à renflouer son activité et survivre au quotidien.
texts.en: Aged 31, this young woman is married to a pastor and is the mother of three children. She got into the business of selling cosmetics in 2007. She buys her merchandise right where she lives and sells it on foot, walking through the streets. This loan will allow her to bail out her business and survive from day to day.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics for resale.

loans.name: Danilon Marina

texts.en:
Danilon Marina is a 35-year-old married woman living in Libag Sur, Tuguegarao City. She has three school-aged children. Danilon Marina's spouse works as a driver in one of the schools in the city.

Danilon Marina has been in the business of hog breeding and fattening for future sale for three years and she earns approximately PHP 5,000 monthly. She is asking for a loan of PHP 15,000. She plans to use this loan to purchase additional pigs to raise and to buy medicines to ensure good nutrition.

In the future, Danilon Marina would like to diversify her business in order to achieve financial independence and continuously send her children to school and have a brighter future.

loans.use: to purchase additional pigs and medicines

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is 53 years old and married with four adult-aged children. He is a farmer working in the Philippines.

Martin grows corn and has been doing this work for twenty years. He earns about 30,000 PHP per harvest season. Martin is asking for a loan of 25,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer and seeds for his farm.

In the future, Martin hopes that his farm's yields will improve to support the needs of his family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seeds for his farm

loans.name: 10 Phú Sơn Group

texts.en:
Hợp is 54 years old. She is married and has two children. She is the leader of a three-member group, the 7.1.10 Phú Sơn solidarity group. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in Thanh Hoa province.

Hợp has a retail business selling dry food. Hợp has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that she faces in her business is the lack of capital. She is requesting a loan to invest in her business. This is Hợp's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

In the future, Hợp hopes for her children's work do well and to upgrade her stall.

loans.use: To purchase more food to resell.

loans.name: Unurtsetseg

texts.en:
Mrs. Unurtsetseg is 52 years old, widowed and lives with her two sons in Darkhan, the second largest city in Mongolia. Her younger son is a truck operator for an ore mine and her other son has graduated the university this year, but he is unemployed now. 

During 1975-2003, she worked in the state's meat-processing plant in her native city. Now, she has been a worker of a meat or gut exporting company since 2003. By the way, she is a responsible worker who has gained much experience from the long duration of her previous employment. Currently, her income is the main living source of this family. Absolutely it’s not enough and it's difficult to raise her children. Therefore, she wants to buy a car for her older son to run a taxi service and then increase the family income. The loan Mrs. Unurtsetseg is taking will be devoted to purchasing a car for a taxi business and then to increasing their family living source with the profits.

loans.use: To purchase a car to start a taxi business

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
En la comunidad de Papel Pata distrito de Echarate (La Convención, Cusco, Perú) conocimos a la señora Francisca y nos cuenta que ella nació en la ciudad de Echarate y que tiene 48 años de edad, ella tiene una unión no matrimonial y de esta relación tiene dos hijas. Actualmente, Francisca  vive en la comunidad de Papel Pata a unos 45 minutos de la ciudad de Quillabamba y donde desarrolla sus actividades económicas. 

Francisca  se dedica a la agricultura específicamente al cultivo de café y cacao, ella lleva sus productos todos los días  a la ciudad de Quillabamba y vende a las personas que se encargan de negociar café y cacao. Desde joven aprendió el oficio pues sus padres le enseñaron el trabajo de la agricultura. Ya son 7 años que se dedica al negocio  y le va muy bien. Francisca  en esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para uso personal ósea para pagar sus gastos de la universidad de sus dos hijas.

El banco comunal “Caminando Juntos” pertenece a la Asociación Arariwa y las reuniones de los socios son cada treinta días en la comunidad de Papel Pata del distrito de Echarate provincia de La Convención del departamento del Cusco.
texts.en:
In the Papel Pata community in Echarate District (La Convención, Cusco, Peru) we met Francisca, and she told us that she was born in the city of Echarate and that she is 48 years old. She has a non-marital relationship, and she has two daughters from this relationship. Currently Francisca lives in the community of Papel Pata, which is about 45 minutes away from the city of Quillabamba and where she carries out her economic activity. 

Francisca works in agriculture, specifically farming coffee and cacao beans. Everyday she brings her products to the city of Quillabamba and sells them to people who deal in coffee and cacao.
